schools.name: College of Arts and Sciences
schools.description: The College of Arts and Sciences confers the Bachelor of Arts in art history, chemistry, classics, communication, English, French and Francophone studies, history, individual studies, Italian studies, music, philosophy, religious studies, Spanish studies, studio art, theatre arts, and gender and sexuality studies; and the Bachelor of Science in social sciences (anthropology, child studies, economics, environmental science, environmental studies, ethnic studies, individual studies, mathematics, political science, psychology, and sociology) and natural sciences (biochemistry, biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering physics, neuroscience, physics, and public health science).

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Total quarter units required for degree

otherNotes: Students must satisfy the requirements of the undergraduate Core Curriculum and the major.
There are no additional college requirements.

Minors offered in African American studies, anthropology, Asian American Studies, art history, biology, chemistry, Chinese and sinophone studies, classics, communication, computer science, creative writing, dance, economics, English, ethnic studies, environmental studies, French and Francophone studies, gerontology, history, Italian studies, Japanese studies, Latina/o/x Studies, mathematics, music, philosophy, physics, political science, professional writing, public health, religious studies, sociology, Spanish studies, studio art, theatre, theatre design and technology, and gender and sexuality studies.

Interdisciplinary minors offered in Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern studies; Asian studies; biotechnology; Catholic studies; international studies; Latin American studies; Premodern studies; musical theatre; sustainability; and urban education.

schools.name: Leavey School of Business
schools.description: The Leavey School of Business confers the Bachelor of Science in Commerce with majors in accounting, accounting and information systems, business analytics, economics, finance, individual studies, management, marketing, and management information systems. It also offers departmental minors in business analytics, management information systems, marketing, and real estate; and interdisciplinary minors in entrepreneurship, international business, retail studies, and sustainable food systems.

thingsNotEncoded: Undergraduate Core Curriculum: requires courses in multiple categories with lists of approved courses (Critical Thinking & Writing 1 & 2; Cultures & Ideas 1, 2, and 3 with MGMT 80 or approved; Second Language; Mathematics; Religion, Theology & Culture 1–3; Ethics; Civic Engagement; Diversity; Arts; Social Science; Natural Science with lab; Science, Technology, and Society; Experiential Learning for Social Justice; Advanced Writing).
Pathways: at least 16 units (usually four courses) from a list of approved courses in one Pathway.

otherNotes: To qualify for the Bachelor of Science in Commerce degree, students must satisfy the requirements of the Undergraduate Core Curriculum, the Leavey School of Business curriculum, and the departmental major.
The School of Business strictly enforces prerequisites; prerequisites must be successfully completed or in progress prior to enrollment in any course that requires them.

Departmental minors offered in business analytics, management information systems, marketing, and real estate; interdisciplinary minors offered in entrepreneurship, international business, retail studies, and sustainable food systems.

Individual Studies major requires an approved petition: full-time SCU enrollment for at least one year, minimum 3.0 GPA, a clear description of the proposed program with unifying themes and learning objectives, evidence no existing major/minor meets objectives, a plan of study with at least eight upper-division courses, and signed approval from a designated faculty advisor.

schools.name: School of Engineering
schools.description: The School of Engineering confers the Bachelor of Science degree with majors in Bioengineering, Civil Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Web Design and Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, General Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering. The specialized programs in Civil, CSE, ECE, EE, and Mechanical Engineering are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, and the CSE program is also accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET. Programs in Bioengineering, General Engineering, and Web Design and Engineering are not yet ABET-accredited. The school offers minors in multiple engineering disciplines and two interdisciplinary minors in Bioengineering and in Technical Innovation, Design Thinking, and the Entrepreneurial Mindset. All undergraduate engineering programs require extensive mathematics and natural science sequences, and prerequisites are strictly enforced.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Biology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Biology offers courses to explore a vast array of biological questions to all students at SCU, including core courses for non-majors, an introductory curriculum that supports all life science majors, and advanced courses leading to the bachelor of science degree. The biology major provides a solid foundation in the core concepts of modern biological thought and critical skills to apply these concepts; it serves as preparation for graduate, medical, or professional studies and for careers in teaching, research, and business. Minor degrees in biology and related disciplines are available.

majors.name: Biology
majors.description: The biology major provides students a solid foundation in the core concepts of modern biological thought and critical skills to apply these concepts; it serves as preparation for graduate, medical, or professional studies and for careers in teaching, research, and business.

thingsNotEncoded: Seven approved upper-division biology courses, including five with a laboratory component.

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to work with faculty on research and can obtain course credit by enrolling in BIOL 195 (research) and BIOL 198 (major research projects).

Students should take at least one upper-division course in each of the five biological concept categories (Evolution, Information Flow, Structure-Function, Systems, and Transformations of Energy and Matter) and at least one upper-division course focusing on modeling and simulation to solve biological problems.

minors.name: Biology
minors.description: The biology minor requires the introductory biology sequence, introductory chemistry prerequisites, and three upper-division biology courses, including two with a laboratory component.

thingsNotEncoded: Two of the three upper-division courses must include a laboratory component.

otherNotes: CHEM 11, 12, and 31 are prerequisites for the introductory biology classes.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Anthropology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Anthropology offers a degree program leading to a Bachelor of Science in anthropology. A solid undergraduate foundation in anthropology secures the analytical skills needed to undertake professional degrees in anthropology, business, law, public health, social services, or provides a foundation for other professional careers. The department also offers a minor, several emphases, and an honors thesis option.

majors.name: Anthropology
majors.description: Provides a Bachelor of Science in anthropology with analytical skills for careers in academia, business, law, public health, social services, and related fields.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Six upper-division courses selected from the following three categories (all three categories must be represented): Archaeology (ANTH 140–149, 173, 186, 189); Biological Anthropology (ANTH 130–139); Cultural Anthropology (ANTH 150–179, 184, 185, 187, 188).

otherNotes: Attending six Anthropology Speaker Series events is required for majors.

minors.name: Anthropology
minors.description: The minor requires ANTH 1 or 2, ANTH 3, one additional lower-division anthropology course, ANTH 110, two approved upper-division anthropology courses, and attendance at four Anthropology Speaker Series events.

thingsNotEncoded: One additional lower-division anthropology course.
Two approved upper-division anthropology courses.

Students gain understanding of how anthropological skills apply in health and medicine, international development, environment, government, business, education, immigration, and poverty.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Neuroscience
deptsAndPrograms.description: A Bachelor of Science degree in neuroscience at SCU will provide students with the scientific foundation needed to understand the nervous system at many levels, from molecular to patient symptomatology. Students will use interdisciplinary approaches to examine the biological, computational, and psychological underpinnings of the nervous system. Students will come to appreciate the interactions between neurological and environmental factors contributing to disease, disorders, and development. They will be challenged to consider ethical issues in neuroscience research and practice. Students who graduate with a neuroscience major will be prepared for diverse careers in health care, policy, business, law, biomedical, and clinical research or in graduate level studies in neuroscience-related disciplines.

Students will come to appreciate the interactions between neurological and environmental factors contributing to disease, disorders, and development. They will be challenged to consider ethical issues in neuroscience research and practice. Students who graduate with a neuroscience major will be prepared for diverse careers in health care, policy, business, law, biomedical, and clinical research or in graduate level studies in neuroscience-related disciplines.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Pre-Law
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Pre-Law program offers advising and support for undergraduates and recent alumni preparing for law school. Advisors guide students in vocational discernment, selecting an undergraduate plan, LSAT preparation, law school applications, and professional development. While no specific major or curriculum is required, the program recommends courses that develop analytical and communication skills. Suggested courses span five categories: Ethics and the Law, Skills for Legal Careers, Institutions and Policy, Justice and Equality, and legal internships.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Chemistry and Biochemistry
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry offers baccalaureate degrees in chemistry and biochemistry, accredited by the American Chemical Society. The curriculum prepares students for careers in industrial and governmental laboratories, graduate and professional programs, and supports interdisciplinary and liberal arts interests through a Bachelor of Arts option. Emphasis is placed on undergraduate research, faculty collaboration, and study abroad flexibility.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Gerontology
deptsAndPrograms.description: Gerontology is an interdisciplinary field focused on the study of older adults, typically defined as age 65 and older. Students engage in hands-on experiences working with older adults in the community and examine how aging intersects with diversity, health, and longevity. The minor develops skills applicable to a wide range of careers and personal journeys.

minors.name: Gerontology
minors.description: Requirements include 29 units total: one lower-division course and five upper-division courses across multiple disciplines. No more than two age-related courses may be taken in any one discipline.

thingsNotEncoded: . Total units required: 29 units, including one lower-division course and five upper-division courses across multiple disciplines
. Discipline cap: No more than two age-related courses may be taken in any one discipline

. Lower-division requirement: One lower-division course that emphasizes different approaches to understanding aging, such as PHSC21 Health and Aging or an introductory course in anthropology, psychology, public health, or sociology
. Upper-division aging-focused courses: ANTH172 Anthropology of Aging and PSYC196 Psychology of Aging
. Applied courses: Two courses providing opportunities to apply course content to age-related issues in disciplines including anthropology, biology, psychology, religious studies, and sociology
. Practicum requirement: GERO198, a 100-hour hands-on service-learning course, internship, or equivalent work engaging directly with older adults

deptsAndPrograms.name: Biotechnology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The minor in biotechnology provides students with a scientific foundation in biotechnology, practical laboratory experience, and insight into ethical and contemporary issues. It is designed for those interested in careers in the biotechnology industry or advanced study in molecular biology, cell biology, or biochemistry. The program requires thirteen courses (most with lab components) and a research internship approved by the director.

minors.name: Biotechnology

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Students must complete a research internship (minimum 10 weeks full-time or 200–300 hours part-time) in a biotechnology-related laboratory, approved by the director, and submit a written report for evaluation.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Mathematics and Computer Science
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Mathematics and Computer Science offers major programs leading to the bachelor of science in mathematics or computer science, as well as required and elective courses for students majoring in other fields. Either major may be pursued with any of three principal goals: preparation for graduate studies leading to advanced degrees in pure mathematics, applied mathematics, computer science, statistics, operations research, or other fields; preparation for secondary school teaching of mathematics or computer science; or preparation for a research career in business, industry, or government. The department maintains a program for the discovery, encouragement, and development of talent in mathematics and computer science among undergraduates, including special sections, seminars, individual conferences, and directed study. Students are encouraged to participate in research projects directed by faculty.

majors.name: Mathematics
majors.description: The mathematics major provides a broad foundation in pure and applied mathematics, with optional emphases in applied mathematics, data science, financial mathematics, mathematical economics, or mathematics education.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Computer Science and Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Computer Science and Engineering offers BS degrees in Computer Science and Engineering and in Web Design and Engineering. The CSE program combines software and hardware engineering with mathematical foundations and allows students to tailor electives in focused areas. The Web Design and Engineering program integrates computing with graphic art, communication, and sociology to address how society uses and is shaped by the Web.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Environmental Studies and Sciences
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Environmental Studies and Sciences (ESS) offers interdisciplinary BS programs in Environmental Science and Environmental Studies, as well as a minor in Environmental Studies. These programs provide students with the foundation to address environmental challenges of the 21st century—such as population growth, urban development, agricultural systems, deforestation, climate change, pollution, biodiversity loss, and renewable energy. The curriculum is enriched by colloquia (ENVS 188), a sophomore seminar (ENVS 198), senior Capstone projects with community stakeholders, approved internships or research experiences, and study abroad opportunities. Students work with faculty advisors to integrate coursework with future career or study plans.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Premodern Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The minor in Premodern Studies offers students from all departments a cross-disciplinary and interdisciplinary program of study of the global premodern period between late antiquity and 1800. These periods lay on the edge of modernity, when the distinctive characteristics of the contemporary world began to form and when major new connections were made between Europe and Africa, the Middle East, East Asia, and the Americas. Study of these periods from many different points of view affords an opportunity to gain valuable perspectives on the ways that premodern people, events, and institutions helped to shape the modern world. Completion of the minor is noted on the student’s transcript, and students receive a certificate acknowledging their accomplishment.

minors.name: Premodern Studies
minors.description: A cross-disciplinary and interdisciplinary program of study of the global premodern period between late antiquity and 1800.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Seven courses selected from three different departments with a maximum of three lower-division courses.

Requirement: One of the upper-division courses must include an interdisciplinary research paper based on source materials and secondary works dealing with a topic rooted in the premodern period. This may be fulfilled by enrolling in a 199 course under supervision of an affiliated faculty member or the program director.
Note: The study of a second language is strongly recommended but not required.

Note: Eligible courses include certain sections of Cultures & Ideas 11A and 12A, special topics/directed reading/directed research/seminar courses in associated departments (including ARTH 97/197, ENGL 97/197, HIST 130, etc.), and courses taken at other institutions or abroad; consult the program director for applicability.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Seven courses selected from three different departments with a maximum of three lower-division courses.

otherNotes: Completion of the minor is noted on the student’s transcript, and students receive a certificate acknowledging their accomplishment.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Information Systems & Analytics
deptsAndPrograms.description: Undergraduate study in the Department of Information Systems and Analytics (ISA) explores the use of computer information systems and analytical decision-making methods in organizations. Essential to the conduct of business, these skills equip the department’s majors and minors to design, implement, and evaluate systems central to an organization’s success. The department offers majors in Business Analytics (BA), Management Information Systems (MIS), and the interdepartmental major of Accounting and Information Systems (AIS). Additionally, it offers two minors: the MIS minor is open for both business and non-business majors, and the minor in Business Analytics is available for business students. The MIS major/minor, AIS major, and Business Analytics major are STEM-designated.

majors.name: Business Analytics
majors.description: The Business Analytics major prepares students with advanced analytical decision-making skills, covering calculus, information systems, advanced business analytics, revenue management, and electives from accounting, economics, finance, and marketing.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Advanced Business Analytics (course number to be determined, anticipated AY 2026-27).
Requirement: Revenue Management and Analytics (course number to be determined, anticipated AY 2026-27).

majors.name: Management Information Systems
majors.description: The Management Information Systems major focuses on foundational and advanced information systems courses, preparing students for roles in systems administration, technical sales, and operations management.

thingsNotEncoded: Non-business students minoring in MIS must also complete one mathematics course (MATH11 or MATH30), one statistics and data analysis course (OMIS40, MATH8, MATH122, PSYC40, COMM110), and three business courses (BUSN70, MGMT160, MKTG181, FNCE121, OMIS108 or OMIS108E).

majors.name: Accounting and Information Systems
majors.description: The interdepartmental Accounting and Information Systems major combines foundational accounting courses with information systems coursework, preparing students for CPA and analytical roles.

thingsNotEncoded: Students must register for ACTG155 to take the CPA exam.
Note: A course cannot be double-dipped in multiple programs. For example, if OMIS113 is taken as an elective for MIS major, it cannot count towards BA minor.

minors.name: Management Information Systems

minors.name: Business Analytics
minors.description: The Business Analytics minor is open to business students and includes foundational and applied analytics courses, with one elective in analytics or related disciplines.

thingsNotEncoded: Prerequisite: OMIS30 is required to enroll in OMIS105, OMIS109, OMIS114, and OMIS115.
Note: A course cannot be double-dipped in multiple programs within the department. For example, if OMIS113 is taken as an elective for the BA minor, it cannot count towards the MIS major.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Child Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Child Studies (CHST) program prepares undergraduates for careers working with children and families in school or community settings. The curriculum emphasizes social justice, anti‐racism, and cultural competence, and students engage extensively with local schools and community‐based programs. Graduates earn a Bachelor of Science degree and are prepared for graduate studies and careers in education, social work, counseling, psychology, law, speech and language pathology, occupational therapy, and nonprofit agencies serving children and families.

majors.name: Child Studies
majors.description: Designed for students interested in careers or graduate studies focused on children and families in school or community contexts, with an emphasis on social‐justice, anti‐racist, and culturally competent perspectives.

thingsNotEncoded: Prerequisite: CHST 11 (or PSYC 51 for double PSYC majors), CHST 12, CHST 100; Recommended: PSYC 185 (ELSJ).

deptsAndPrograms.name: Electrical and Computer Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Electrical and Computer Engineering Department offers programs leading to the bachelor of science in electrical engineering or the bachelor of science in electrical and computer engineering, and provides required and elective courses for students majoring in other fields. Electrical and computer engineering covers the design, construction, and operation of electrical components, circuits, and systems as well as the science and technology of software and hardware components of modern computing systems, embedded systems, and computer-controlled equipment. Areas include sustainable energy and electric power, signal and image processing, machine learning, embedded systems, control systems, robotics, nanotechnology and integrated circuits, antennas, RF and communication systems, and information storage, compression, and transmission. Laboratories are integral to undergraduate courses, with five teaching labs supporting electric circuits, electronics, signal processing and control systems, logic design and digital and embedded systems, and RF and communication, plus a senior design laboratory and access to the Engineering Computing Center facilities.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering

deptsAndPrograms.name: Individual Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Individual Studies Program (ISP) allows students to design a multidisciplinary course of study leading to a Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science in social science. The major requires courses from a significant number of different disciplines (preferably existing catalog courses rather than independent study), limits study abroad courses to four, and is overseen by a faculty advisor who reviews and approves all coursework and provides annual advising.

majors.name: Individual Studies
majors.description: Enables students to design a customized, interdisciplinary program of study leading to a BA or BS in social science under faculty advisor supervision.

thingsNotEncoded: Full-time requirement: Be a full-time student at Santa Clara for at least one year.
Unit limit: Have fewer than 111 quarter units of academic work completed at time of application.
GPA requirement: Minimum 3.0 grade point average.

Admission petition: Submit a Petition for Admission including a clear, logical description of the proposed program, justification that no existing major meets the objectives, a detailed plan of study, and confirmation of academic advisor commitment.
Study abroad limit: No more than four courses taken abroad may be used in the proposed plan of study.

Faculty advisor requirement: Must secure a faculty advisor who agrees to oversee the major, review and approve coursework (including electives and substitutions), and provide at least annual advising.
Initial meeting: Students should schedule a meeting with the program director for instructions on administrative procedures.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Philosophy
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Philosophy offers a degree program leading to the Bachelor of Arts in philosophy. Philosophy inquires directly into the relation of human beings to the world: what we are, how we know, what values are, how we live. Worth pursuing for its own sake, philosophical inquiry also promotes analytical thinking and precise expression and, thus, is excellent undergraduate preparation for a number of professional careers in areas such as law, government, finance, media, writing, and computer programming.

majors.name: Philosophy
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy

thingsNotEncoded: Waiver: Lower-division course requirement is waived for students who completed a Foundations Core sequence in Philosophy (PHIL 1A/2A or PHIL 11A/12A).
Note: No one class may fulfill both the Non-Western Philosophy and the History of Philosophy requirement.
Note: To qualify as an upper-division elective, any PHIL 199 class must be 5 units.

minors.name: Philosophy
minors.description: Minor in Philosophy requires PHIL 14 and PHIL 15, PHIL 17 or PHIL 18, and four upper-division PHIL courses.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Medical and Health Humanities
deptsAndPrograms.description: Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.

minors.name: Medical and Health Humanities
minors.description: Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.

thingsNotEncoded: Courses not included in the list of approved courses may count towards the minor with approval of the program directors.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Health Professions Advising
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Health Professions Advising program provides comprehensive advising, mentoring, and support for Santa Clara University students pursuing careers in healthcare fields—such as dentistry, medicine (allopathic and osteopathic), physical therapy, optometry, pharmacy, and more. The program uses national acceptance data and best practices to guide students in preparation, promotes all majors as viable “pre-health” pathways, and dispels misconceptions about “best” majors. Advising is delivered through individual appointments with the University Health Professions Advisor, a dedicated Camino course site with modular resources (e.g., curriculum planning, career exploration, clinical experiences, testing support, application guidance, and professional programming), and a team of 12 Health Professions Peer Advisors who offer one-on-one and drop-in advising, workshops, event support, and a weekly newsletter. The program enrolls around 600 students, leverages partnerships with healthcare providers for experiential learning, maintains communication via surveys and mailing lists, and engages alumni through a LinkedIn group.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Finance
deptsAndPrograms.description: Finance is at the center of well-managed businesses, from high-technology companies to mutual fund companies. The development of knowledge and managerial skills in the corporate and investment settings are the major goals of the finance program. Graduates with a degree in finance pursue careers as corporate financial officers, traders, investment managers, financial analysts, financial planners, investment bankers, stockbrokers, regulators, and other specialties. Corporate finance officers manage the assets and value of corporations. They examine which new products and investments will be profitable, analyze the most cost-effective ways to produce them and determine where to get the money needed to fund new ventures. Personal financial planners and stockbrokers help people make wise investments by selecting good stocks and assembling efficient portfolios. Students in finance also learn how to understand and analyze information from capital markets, engage in mergers and acquisitions, and undertake investments in new ventures, real estate, and international markets.

majors.name: Finance
majors.description: The finance major prepares students for careers in corporate finance, investment management, financial analysis, planning, and related fields by developing knowledge and managerial skills in corporate and investment settings.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: FNCE 186 qualifies as one of the four upper-division finance electives required for finance majors.
Note: FNCE 118, FNCE 127, FNCE 129, and FNCE 131 do NOT satisfy upper-division elective requirements for finance majors and are not included in the finance major GPA.

minors.name: Real Estate
minors.description: The Real Estate minor provides grounding in real estate transactions and elective topics. All students must complete core real estate coursework and a selection of electives from primary and secondary lists.

thingsNotEncoded: Elective Requirements: Business School Students must complete 3 electives from the Primary Elective List; Non-Business School Students must complete 4 electives (3 electives if they have taken BUSN 70 or BUSN 170, ACTG 11 or ACTG 11A, and FNCE 121) from the Primary and Secondary Elective Lists, with at most one elective from the Secondary Elective List.
Primary Elective List: FNCE 127/FNCE 129, FNCE 128, FNCE 131, ECON 156, ENVS 116, ENVS 128, CENG 118, CENG 119.
Secondary Elective List (max one): CENG 128, FNCE 143, OMIS 114, OMIS 115, OMIS 116, OMIS 118, MKTG 189.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Urban Education
deptsAndPrograms.description: The interdisciplinary minor provides students seeking to become elementary or secondary teachers with foundational coursework in educational theory, urban school observation and reflection, U.S. constitutional history, and sociological and psychological foundations of education, while focusing on societal issues such as poverty, crime, and prejudice and their impact on youth and families. Recommended for students from diverse majors interested in careers working directly with children and families from multicultural backgrounds.

minors.name: Urban Education
minors.description: Provides foundational courses necessary for a career in education and focuses on societal problems impacting youth and families, recommended for those interested in elementary or secondary teaching.
otherNotes: Only two (2) courses in a student’s major can be used to fulfill requirements in the urban education minor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Classics
deptsAndPrograms.description: Classics is the study of all aspects of the life and culture of ancient Greece and Rome in their Mediterranean context and their enduring relevance to our lives. The Department offers all levels of ancient Greek and Latin, as well as interdisciplinary courses exploring the origins of Western literature, history, art, mythology, philosophy, religion, ethics, government, science, architecture, engineering, and city planning. Most courses require no prior language knowledge and are open to all students. Latin or ancient Greek may be taken to satisfy the second language requirement. Classics provides an ideal liberal arts curriculum and background for many careers.

majors.name: Classics
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Classics. Students choose one of three tracks: Classical Languages and Literatures, Classical Studies, or Ancient Studies.

thingsNotEncoded: In addition to fulfilling undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the bachelor of arts degree, students must complete the departmental requirements for the chosen track

minors.name: Classics

deptsAndPrograms.name: Asian Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Asian Studies minor provides an introduction to the cultures and languages of Asia. Courses in several disciplines enable students to sample different dimensions of Asian cultures, as well as focus on a specific area of interest.

minors.name: Asian Studies
minors.description: The Asian Studies minor provides an introduction to the cultures and languages of Asia. Courses in several disciplines enable students to sample different dimensions of Asian cultures and focus on a specific area of interest. Students are strongly urged to spend a summer or quarter in one of the University-approved study abroad programs in Asia.

thingsNotEncoded: Restriction: Maximum of two upper-division culture courses from a student's major and a maximum of three upper-division culture courses in any one department.
Note: Culture courses include approved offerings in disciplines such as art history, communication, history, philosophy, political science, and religious studies.

Note: Students may demonstrate equivalent proficiency by passing a language proficiency examination supervised by the Department of Modern Languages and Literatures or by presenting professionally recognized documentation of proficiency in an Asian language.

otherNotes: Students are strongly urged to spend a summer or quarter in one of the University-approved study abroad programs in Asia.
Courses about the Asian American experience are considered ethnic studies courses and do not count for the Asian Studies minor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: International Business
deptsAndPrograms.description: The International Business minor is designed to educate students in a broad range of management and business skills in a global context, including language, social science, and international business coursework. The program provides an understanding of international business’s social, economic, and political contexts and the language, communication, and business skills needed to be effective managers in a global marketplace. Students are encouraged to participate in study abroad programs or internships to complement this minor.

minors.name: International Business
minors.description: The International Business minor prepares students with language, social science, and business coursework to understand global social, economic, and political contexts and develop skills for managing in a global marketplace.

thingsNotEncoded: Foreign Language note: Students who feel that they already have the required language competency must demonstrate this by completing one of the above courses (or a more advanced 100- or 101-level course). Other languages do not qualify.

World Geography or Social Science requirement: Two approved Cultures & Ideas 3 courses in anthropology, history, political science, or sociology; OR two courses from the following list: ENVS 50; ECON 129, 134, 138; HIST 105; POLI 50, 119, 121, 122, 136, 137, 140, 142, 144, 146; PSYC 162; SOCI 138; OR a combination of one course from each option. Other eligible selected comparative politics courses may be approved by the director of the International Business Minor Program.
International Business note: Some courses may require prerequisites and are offered only once a year.

otherNotes: Completion of advanced language courses.
Participation in study abroad programs; approved equivalent courses taken abroad may fulfill the minor’s requirements.
Internship related to an international business career.
Additional coursework in economic development, modern history, and politics of selected world regions.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Entrepreneurship
deptsAndPrograms.description: The entrepreneurship minor provides students interested in developing a business or working in a startup company the chance to explore that career option and acquire the skills to help them succeed. Students develop an understanding of the venture creation process, including how to generate and develop a new business concept, apply analytical tools to identify and evaluate entrepreneurial opportunities, create and evaluate a business plan, and analyze different funding sources for a new venture. A critical element of the program is an internship with an emerging for-profit or social benefit organization.

minors.name: Entrepreneurship

A critical element of the program is an internship with an emerging for-profit or social benefit organization.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: The internship must run concurrently with the course, and students cannot use past experiences toward credit in this course.

otherNotes: Open to all students via an application process through the Management and Entrepreneurship Department.

Accepted business school students can begin the minor after they have earned 60 units.
Students outside the business school should ideally complete prerequisites for the core courses in the sophomore year.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Economics
deptsAndPrograms.description: As one of the social sciences, economics studies how individual choices—as consumers and producers, savers and investors, managers and employees, citizens and voters—combine to determine how society uses scarce resources to produce and distribute goods and services. The rigorous, systematic analysis of issues such as wealth and poverty, unemployment, inflation, international trade, and economic growth prepares graduates for careers in the private and public sectors and for graduate study in economics, business, public policy, and law.

majors.name: Economics
majors.description: The economics major provides a rigorous foundation in microeconomic and macroeconomic theory, quantitative methods, and economic analysis, preparing students for careers in the private and public sectors and for graduate study.

thingsNotEncoded: At least two of the five upper-division economics electives must be completed after ECON 113 and 115.

otherNotes: Prerequisites: Unless otherwise noted, a grade of C- or better in ECON 1, 2, and 3 is required for all upper-division economics courses.
Students considering graduate study in economics are strongly encouraged to meet with their advisor as early as possible to plan an appropriate course of study.

minors.name: Economics
minors.description: The economics minor offers foundational courses in economic theory and quantitative methods, along with additional upper-division electives to deepen understanding of economic principles.

thingsNotEncoded: Two additional upper-division economics courses must be in addition to ECON 113 and 115.

emphases.name: Data Analysis for Economics
emphases.description: The concentration in Data Analysis for Economics develops advanced skills in econometrics and data analysis through specialized coursework, applying quantitative methods to economic and related issues.

thingsNotEncoded: Substitution: One (and only one) of the courses in list C may be substituted with an approved course in another social science or business discipline (CSCI183, ENVS117, OMIS114, or OMIS150) or an independent study course with substantial data analysis component; substitutions must be approved by the Concentration advisor. Non-economics courses do not count as upper-division electives toward the economics major.
Note: All upper-division courses in the concentration count as upper-division electives toward the economics major.

emphases.name: Mathematical Economics
emphases.description: The concentration in Mathematical Economics provides advanced mathematical training for economics majors, integrating higher-level mathematics and theoretical economics courses.

thingsNotEncoded: Recommended: MATH 122 and 123.
Note: Students completing the mathematical economics concentration take MATH 11 and 12 instead of MATH 30 and 31.
Note: Courses in list C also count as electives required for the economics major.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Musical Theatre
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Musical Theatre Minor offers experience and training in music, theatre, and dance, as well as musical theatre history. The objectives of this program include entry-level proficiency for a career in performance, enhancement in teaching, or further training in graduate school; audition techniques; performance of acting, singing, and theatrical dance; and knowledge of the cultural history and various forms of musical theatre. Students may, through repertoire choices decided in consultation with their instructors, focus their vocal work with emphasis on a Broadway or more Opera style.

The objectives of this program include entry-level proficiency for a career in performance, enhancement in teaching, or further training in graduate school; audition techniques; performance of acting, singing, and theatrical dance; and knowledge of the cultural history and various forms of musical theatre. Students may, through repertoire choices decided in consultation with their instructors, focus their vocal work with emphasis on a Broadway or more Opera style.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sustainable Food Systems
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Sustainable Food Systems minor provides students with the opportunity to explore the intersection of global food systems and sustainability. Courses address the cultural aspects of food, food policies, nutrition and public health, social justice, sustainability, and opportunities for creating new innovation and change within the food system. The minor will prepare students for future careers in food industry management, food entrepreneurship, food policy, public health, and nutrition.

minors.name: Sustainable Food Systems
minors.description: The Sustainable Food Systems minor provides students with the opportunity to explore the intersection of global food systems and sustainability. Courses address the cultural aspects of food, food policies, nutrition and public health, social justice, sustainability, and opportunities for creating new innovation and change within the food system.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Music
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Music offers a degree program leading to the bachelor of arts in music as well as a minor in music. A minor in musical theatre is available in conjunction with the Department of Theatre and Dance. The Department of Music’s curriculum is designed to provide students of diverse backgrounds with the skills necessary to comprehend, perform, and appreciate music’s role in human history and its power to enhance the lives of all people. Membership in departmental music ensembles is available to all Santa Clara students and applied instruction is available to Music and Theatre majors and minors and students participating in departmental ensembles.

majors.name: Music
majors.description: The bachelor of arts in music curriculum is designed to provide students with the skills necessary to comprehend, perform, and appreciate music’s role in human history and its power to enhance the lives of all people.
otherNotes: Note: These ensemble courses meet the ensemble requirement for music majors and minors, and may be repeated for credit.
Note: Individual applied instruction lessons may be 1.0 or 0.5 units, may be repeated for credit, and follow the protocols on the Department of Music website.

minors.name: Music
minors.description: The minor in music provides foundational and elective coursework in music theory, aural skills, music history, applied instruction, ensemble participation, and the Music at Noon series.
otherNotes: Note: Students may take a Music Theory Placement Exam to test into a course that is appropriate for their skill level, but must still complete two courses from both the Theory and Musicianship sequences.

errors: Under 'Requirements for the Major', the introductory sentence incorrectly refers to a minor in music.

deptsAndPrograms.name: International Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The International Studies Minor enables students to study global issues or problems, or focus on a geographic area—Africa, Europe or Latin America—through an interdisciplinary lens. It provides a framework for adding a global dimension to a major or preparation for a career working with diverse, intercultural teams. The minor consists of four Foundation courses; three Emphasis courses; plus a Capstone.

minors.name: International Studies
minors.description: The International Studies Minor enables students to study global issues or problems, or focus on a geographic area—Africa, Europe or Latin America—through an interdisciplinary lens. It provides a framework for adding a global dimension to a major or preparation for a career working with diverse, intercultural teams. The minor consists of four Foundation courses; three Emphasis courses; plus a Capstone.

thingsNotEncoded: Foundation Courses: Choose two social science courses (one must be from courses indicated with an '*') and two upper-division modern language courses in a language related to the chosen emphasis or equivalent through placement examination.
Emphasis Courses: Choose three courses from either the Global Thematic Emphasis or Area Studies Emphasis.

Capstone Course: A minimum of 20 contact hours in a class, academic internship, or community-based learning experience abroad with academic oversight and assessment; may be fulfilled by one quarter study abroad or an alternative capstone course approved by the Associate Provost for International Programs.

emphases.name: Global Thematic
emphases.description: Global Thematic Emphasis offers students the opportunity to focus on international issues transcending a single nation or geographic area, such as poverty and development, global health, international law and human rights, and more.

thingsNotEncoded: Global Thematic Emphasis: Choose three courses, at least two of which must be upper division and no more than one from the student's academic major, focusing on a global thematic issue. Examples include poverty and development; global health; international law and human rights; global sustainability and climate change; peace and conflict resolution; cross-cultural communication; international social justice in the arts; community arts in a global context; technology and globalization; the global dimensions of natural and physical sciences; diplomacy; gender and society; international women's rights.

emphases.name: Area Studies
emphases.description: Area Studies Emphasis allows students to focus on a selected geographic area—Africa, Europe, or Latin America—through an interdisciplinary introduction to the cultures, languages, politics, and global challenges facing the region, including study of the African diaspora, slavery, colonialism, and globalization for the Africa emphasis.

thingsNotEncoded: Area Studies Emphasis: Choose three courses, at least two of which must be upper division and no more than one from the student's academic major, focusing on Africa (including African diaspora and related issues), Europe, or Latin America. Courses cover cultures, languages, politics, and global challenges of the region.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Pre-Teaching
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Pre-Teaching program provides guidance and preparation for students pursuing California teaching credentials at the elementary, middle, or high school level. It outlines recommended undergraduate coursework, credential requirements (including the U.S. Constitution, CSET or subject-matter waiver for single-subject, basic educational skills, professional education with field experience, and teaching performance assessment), and opportunities such as the Future Teachers Project (FTP) and combined Master of Arts in Teaching and Teaching Credential (MATTC) program.

minors.name: Urban Education
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor recommended for students planning TK–12 teaching, which includes pre-teaching coursework and field-based learning placements.

thingsNotEncoded: See the Interdisciplinary Minors and Other Programs of Study section for specific course requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Civil, Environmental and Sustainable Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: Offers an undergraduate BS program in civil engineering focused on planning, design, construction, and maintenance of infrastructure systems with sustainability and resilience. The department’s educational objectives include technical competence in infrastructure systems, ethical and responsible service, and lifelong learning. It also offers a combined BS/MS program allowing students to begin master’s coursework early (up to 20 overlapping units) and requiring 46 additional MS units. Facilities include state-of-the-art environmental, geotechnical, hydraulics, computational, structural, materials, surveying, and traffic engineering laboratories.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.description: The Civil Engineering major includes foundational courses in English, mathematics, natural sciences, core engineering, and specialized civil engineering coursework, with technical and free electives, preparing students for professional practice or advanced studies.

thingsNotEncoded: Core Curriculum: Students must fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the bachelor of science degree.
Free elective: One free elective (4 units).

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Minimum total units for BS in Civil Engineering

minors.name: Construction Management
minors.description: The Construction Management minor requires completion of core construction management courses and 6 elective units for a total of at least 22 units; up to 14 units may overlap with major or core requirements.

thingsNotEncoded: Double-dip: Students may double-dip up to 14 units of coursework to concurrently satisfy major or core requirements.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Minimum total units for Construction Management minor

deptsAndPrograms.name: Accounting
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Accounting department strives to provide high-quality accounting instruction, conduct research that contributes to the understanding of accounting issues, and offer superior service to students, alumni, the profession, the University, and the business community. In addition to a standalone Accounting major, it offers a joint Accounting and Information Systems major (A&IS), which has a STEM designation effective September 2023.

majors.name: Accounting
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Commerce major focusing on accounting principles, practices, and professional preparation.
otherNotes: Note: Accounting majors may use ACTG 134 to satisfy both the information systems requirement in the Leavey School of Business curriculum and the Science, Technology & Society requirement in the University Core.

majors.name: Accounting and Information Systems
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Commerce joint major blending accounting and information systems, with STEM designation effective Fall 2023.
otherNotes: Note: Accounting and information systems majors may use OMIS 30 to satisfy the information systems requirement in the Leavey School of Business curriculum. OMIS 150 is cross-listed with ACTG 155. Accounting and information systems majors are required to enroll in ACTG 155.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Applied Mathematics
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Applied Mathematics offers only graduate degree programs and operates in a service mode at the undergraduate level. Undergraduate courses offered by the department have been designed to bridge mathematical theory and engineering applications.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sustainability
deptsAndPrograms.description: The sustainability minor helps students discover the connections and balance among a healthy environment, just societies, and a vibrant economy that meet all people’s fundamental needs currently and in the future, especially those of the global poor. Courses explore the environmental, societal, and economic aspects of sustainability, and how to take action to improve sustainability.

minors.name: Sustainability
minors.description: The sustainability minor helps students discover the connections and balance among a healthy environment, just societies, and a vibrant economy that meet all people’s fundamental needs currently and in the future, especially those of the global poor. Courses explore the environmental, societal, and economic aspects of sustainability, and how to take action to improve sustainability.

thingsNotEncoded: Overall requirement: 8 courses total—1 foundational, 2 environmental (min 6 units), 2 societal (min 6 units), 2 economic (min 6 units), and 1 action learning course.
Limit: No more than 3 courses may come from a student’s major.
Foundational course: ENVS95.

Environmental dimension courses: ANTH160, BIOL5, BIOL6, BIOL134, BIOL156, ENVS156, BIOL180, CENG20, CENG115, CENG119, CENG122, CENG123, CENG124, ENVS124, CENG139, CENG140, CENG142, CENG143, CENG144, CENG160, CENG161, CENG162, CHEM101, ENGR60, ENVS5, ENVS21, ENVS22, ENVS23, ENVS145, ENVS160, ENVS166, ENVS180, ENVS185, MECH121, MECH125, MGMT40, MECH144, ENGR144, MECH163, PHYS120.

Societal dimension courses: ANTH50, ANTH140, ANTH154, ANTH159, COMM137S (ENGL107S), COMM157, COMM158, ECON129, ECON160, ENGL176, ENGR1, ENGR1L, ENGR11A, ENGR16, ENGR19, ENGR110, ENGR161 (MGMT177), ENVS22, ENVS128, ENVS131, ENVS146, ENVS155, PHIL29, PHIL29H, PHYS192, POLI123, RSOC64, SCTR111, SOCI33, SOCI132, SOCI134, SOCI137, SOCI138, SOCI140, SOCI141, SOCI164, SOCI175 (ETHN195), TESP26, TESP150, TESP152.

Economic dimension courses: ACTG140, BUSN70, BUSN150, BUSN170, CENG128, ECON101 (MGMT173), ECON111, ENGR171A, ENGR173, FNCE130, MGMT6, MGMT41, MGMT80, MGMT168, MGMT176, MKTG189, OMIS108E, PHIL26, POLI40.

Action learning courses: BUSN132, COMM158, DANC69, DANC169, ELSJ135, ENGR2, ENGR110, ENGR111, ENGR136, ENVS144 (MECH144), ENVS77, ENVS195, MGMT42, plus other approved credit-bearing courses or fellowship programs (e.g., internships, study abroad, Washington Semester, research projects, senior design), excluding ESS internships.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Mechanical Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: Mechanical Engineering applies physics, mathematics, and materials science to the design and realization of mechanical and thermal systems. The undergraduate curriculum provides a rigorous theoretical foundation coupled with hands-on laboratories and projects, emphasizes moral, ethical, and social impacts alongside entrepreneurial thinking, and trains students as engineers of conscience, competence, and compassion.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.description: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering requires a minimum of 192 units and completion of departmental requirements in English, mathematics and natural science, engineering fundamentals, mechanical engineering core courses, and technical electives.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Students must fulfill the undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the bachelor of science degree.

Technical Electives: 12 units of technical electives to be satisfied by pre-approved upper-division MECH courses, graduate courses (with major GPA ≥3.0), up to 4 units of Co-Op (MECH 188 & MECH 189), and/or up to 8 units of MECH 199; a maximum of 8 units used to fulfill another major/minor may count; courses from other departments require departmental approval.

otherNotes: Combined Bachelor of Science and Master of Science Program: Under the combined degree program, students may begin taking graduate courses during their senior year and complete the M.S. in Mechanical Engineering at the end of the fifth year; they must enroll between February of junior year and December of senior year; the bachelor’s degree is awarded after standard requirements; the master’s requires 46 additional units beyond those applied to the bachelor’s degree; no course may satisfy both degrees.

minors.name: Mechanical Engineering
minors.description: The minor in Mechanical Engineering provides foundational exposure to mechanical engineering laboratory and core courses, plus electives and a technical sequence.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: Please be aware of the prerequisites for the technical sequence courses; this may influence your choice of lower-division courses.

minors.name: Aerospace Engineering
minors.description: The minor in Aerospace Engineering is open to all undergraduates and requires foundational mechanical engineering courses, an introduction to aerospace engineering, and aerospace courses at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: All undergraduates are eligible; students intending to earn this minor should seek advice from the Mechanical Engineering Department.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Marketing
deptsAndPrograms.description: Marketing operates at the cutting edge of a well-managed organization, linking businesses to markets and customers, anticipating needs, handling communications, and guiding strategic decisions. The department emphasizes innovation, high technology, retailing, and digital marketing, preparing students for careers in general management, advertising, retailing, sales, brand management, and market research.

majors.name: Marketing
majors.description: Students develop decision-making and managerial skills through core and elective marketing courses, preparing for general management careers or specialized roles in advertising, retailing, sales, brand management, and market research.
otherNotes: Note: MKTG 198 internship cannot be substituted for an elective course in the major.

minors.name: Marketing
minors.description: The Marketing minor provides a foundation in customer-centered focus, decision processes, and strategy development, with electives to strengthen strategic, creative, and analytical marketing skills.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: MKTG 181 is a prerequisite for other Marketing courses.

Requirement: Marketing electives used to fulfill the requirements of another minor may not be double-counted. For example, MKTG165 will not count toward the Marketing minor if also pursuing a Retail Studies minor.

otherNotes: The minor is open to Business and non-Business students with junior standing beginning Fall 25 via an online application process. Declaration requires admission through an application in Winter quarter, with notifications in Spring quarter and enrollment beginning the following Fall quarter.

emphases.name: Business and Technology Marketing
emphases.description: An emphasis to guide students interested in courses at the intersection of business and technology within marketing.

emphases.name: Consumer and Channel Marketing
emphases.description: An emphasis to guide students interested in consumer behavior and channel strategy within marketing.

emphases.name: Individually Designed Marketing
emphases.description: An emphasis allowing students to select three marketing courses in consultation with a faculty advisor, typically from the department’s elective offerings.
otherNotes: Note: An emphasis will not appear on a student’s transcript.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Retail Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Retail Studies minor, offered by the Retail Management Institute, provides an in-depth, hands-on experience preparing students for diverse roles in retail—including e-commerce, buying, merchandising, planning and allocation, digital marketing, and supply chain management. The program features core junior- and senior-year courses covering topics such as digital marketing, branding, product development, category management, business analytics, supply chain management, e-commerce, and pricing and promotion analysis, along with a junior-year internship and opportunities for corporate visits, conference participation, and scholarships.

minors.name: Retail Studies
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor open to all undergraduates, combining foundational courses in business, communication, data analysis, technology, economics, management, marketing, and retail-specific seminars with a required internship and industry engagements.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: BUSN 179 is available to business students only.
Prerequisite: COMM 1 and COMM 2 are prerequisites for COMM 110.
Prerequisite: BUSN 70 followed by ACTG 11 and MKTG 181 are prerequisites for MKTG 165.
Note: MKTG 168 is offered in Fall Quarter only.
Prerequisite: MKTG 165 is a prerequisite for MKTG 168.
Note: MKTG 169 is offered in Winter Quarter only.
Prerequisite: MKTG 168 and MKTG 165 are prerequisites for MKTG 169.

otherNotes: Non-business majors are encouraged to apply during their first or second year to integrate the retail minor with their major requirements.
Business students must complete lower-division requirements and enter the program by January of their junior year.
Admission to the minor is at the discretion of the Executive Director based on criteria including a minimum GPA of 3.3, analytical and creative thinking ability, and prior exposure to retail.
Students complete a required junior-year internship and have opportunities for corporate visits, conference participation, and scholarships.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Latin American Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: Through interdisciplinary study of Latin America and its diaspora, this minor helps students develop global competence, cross-cultural awareness, appreciation of social diversity and inclusion, and understanding of connections between the region and diasporic communities. It prepares students for careers in business, government and public service, international marketing, law, and nonprofit organizations, and provides a foundation for graduate studies in disciplines such as Anthropology, History, Political Science, and Sociology.

minors.name: Latin American Studies
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor focusing on the languages, cultures, societies, history, and diaspora of Latin America. Students must demonstrate language proficiency and complete a sequence of foundational, elective, and diaspora courses to build regional and cross-cultural expertise.

thingsNotEncoded: Language Requirement: Successful completion of an upper-division SPAN course (level 100 or above) or equivalent Spanish or Portuguese proficiency exam, or completion of one upper-division course in Latin American literature and culture taught in Spanish. Only courses dealing with Latin America count toward the 7-course requirement.
Foundational Course I: One course on Latin America between the Precolumbian Era and late 19th century (e.g., ANTH 185, ANTH 186, ARTH 11, ARTH 25, HIST 166, SPAN 140).
Foundational Course II: One course on Latin America from the wars of independence to present (e.g., HIST 95, SPAN 137, SPAN 146, SPAN 147).

Latin American Electives: Four courses dealing substantially with Latin America; courses used for Foundational I or II may not be reused. Departments offering electives include Anthropology, Art History, English, Environmental Studies, History, Modern Languages (Spanish), Political Science, Public Health Science, Religious Studies, and Sociology.

Latin American Diaspora Elective: One course on Latine communities outside Latin America (e.g., ENGL 36, ENGL 136, ETHN 20, RSOC 12, SPAN 176, etc.); a seminar, senior thesis, or independent study may also fulfill this requirement with approval.

Additional Requirements: Total of seven courses, at least four upper-division; courses must be chosen from at least three different departments; substantial credit from study abroad or immersive experiences may be approved for credit with significant written work upon return; in specific circumstances a course may be approved for either Foundational I or II but may not satisfy both; students may take more than one Foundational I or II course toward electives.

otherNotes: Juniors and seniors may design an independent study in lieu of one elective with program director and affiliated faculty approval.

Students are encouraged to focus on Latin American/Latine peoples and cultures for the Core Curriculum experiential learning requirement, to participate in Latin American study abroad programs (courses abroad may count toward minor requirements), and to consult the program director before enrolling in study abroad.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Catholic Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The minor in Catholic Studies is an interdisciplinary program open to all students, designed for intensive study of the intellectual tradition of the Catholic faith across multiple cultures and academic disciplines. Minors are assigned a faculty mentor and, in partnership with the Ignatian Center for Jesuit Education, the program sponsors intellectual, cultural, social, and religious opportunities for students and faculty.

minors.name: Catholic Studies
minors.description: A minor focusing on foundational courses in Catholic theology, the role of Catholicism in culture and history, specialized philosophy or theology study, electives on Catholic societies or cultures, and a capstone colloquium.

thingsNotEncoded: Foundational Courses: Two courses in Catholic theology from offerings in the Department of Religious Studies
Foundational Courses: One approved course from the Cultures & Ideas Series (or equivalent)
Faith and Culture Courses: One course that explores Catholicism’s role in world history
Faith and Culture Courses: One course that explores Catholicism’s contributions in the arts or in literature
Faith and Culture Courses: One specialized course in philosophy or an upper-division course in theology
Faith and Culture Courses: Two approved elective courses in the study of Catholic societies or cultures
Colloquium Course: One colloquium course (specific offering not listed)

otherNotes: Minors are assigned a faculty mentor who guides them through the program
In conjunction with the Ignatian Center for Jesuit Education, the program sponsors intellectual, cultural, social, and religious opportunities for students and faculty

deptsAndPrograms.name: Psychology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Psychology offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Psychology. Psychology is the study of behavior, emotion, and thought using the scientific method within a liberal arts education, laying the groundwork for various careers and advanced studies, including graduate degrees and professional practice.

majors.name: Psychology
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Psychology provides a liberal arts foundation for understanding behavior, emotion, and thought through scientific methods, preparing students for diverse careers and graduate studies.
otherNotes: Students must fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the Bachelor of Science degree in addition to these departmental requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Public Health
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Public Health offers a Bachelor of Science degree in public health, a minor in public health, and manages the Global Health Pathway of the University Core. The interdisciplinary major examines structural, social, environmental, and biological determinants of health through required and elective coursework, culminating in a senior capstone and a required internship. Two emphases—Health Science and Health and Society—customize the curriculum. Graduates are prepared for careers, graduate education, or professional training in public health and related fields; students are encouraged to study abroad and pre-health students should consult the pre-health advisor regarding additional prerequisites.

majors.name: Public Health Science
majors.description: Interdisciplinary major focused on population and individual health, exploring structural, social, environmental, and biological influences through core PHSC courses, electives across sciences and humanities, a capstone project, and a required internship.
otherNotes: 100+ Hour Internship Requirement: PHSC major requires students to complete at least 100 hours of approved public health-related internship work, which may be part-time or full-time and for credit or volunteer service.

minors.name: Public Health
minors.description: Introduces students to public health principles with a foundation in biological and social sciences and statistical methods. Upper-division electives examine influences on health across environmental, cultural, economic, and historical contexts. Students may petition to include new relevant courses.

thingsNotEncoded: Upper-Division Elective Courses: At least three approved courses, including courses from at least two departments

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to petition the Chair of the Department to consider new relevant courses developed at Santa Clara University and partner institutions abroad.

emphases.name: Health Science
emphases.description: Emphasis integrating public health core coursework with biological sciences, chemistry, social sciences, mathematics, statistics, and elective coursework, culminating in a 100-hour internship.

thingsNotEncoded: Two approved introductory social science courses
Two approved upper-division biomedical electives (at least one with a lab component)
Two approved upper-division social science or humanities electives
Approved 100-hour internship

emphases.name: Health and Society
emphases.description: Emphasis focused on social and societal aspects of public health, combining core public health courses with biology, social science, mathematics, and statistics, including a 100-hour internship.

thingsNotEncoded: Six approved introductory social science courses (chosen from two departments)
Three approved upper-division social science electives
Approved 100-hour internship

deptsAndPrograms.name: Bioengineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: Bioengineering focuses on the application of engineering principles to biological systems, educating students to solve problems at the interface of engineering and the life sciences. The department offers a bioengineering major preparing students for careers in medical device, biotechnology, and biopharmaceutical industries, graduate study, or medical school; a bioengineering minor for students in other disciplines; and a minor in healthcare innovation and design.

majors.name: Bioengineering
majors.description: Designed to prepare students for careers in the medical device, biotechnology and biopharmaceutical industries, graduate study in bioengineering, or entry into medical school. Students complete a minimum of 191 units, core engineering and BioE courses, choose a track (biomolecular, medical-device, or pre-med), complete a senior design sequence, and take technical electives.

thingsNotEncoded: English: ENGL 181
Bioethics: one course from BIOE 180, BIOL 171, ENGR 19, PHIL 27, PHIL 117, or TESP 157

Natural Science requirements: choose one track—Biomolecular (BIOE 21, 22; CHEM 11, 12, 31, 32; PHYS 31, 32, 33), Medical-device (BIOE 21, 22; CHEM 11, 12, 31; PHYS 31, 32, 33), or Pre-med (BIOL 1A, 1B, 1C*; BIOE 24 or 25; CHEM 11, 12, 31, 32, 33; PHYS 31, 32, 33)
Mathematics: MATH 11, 12, 13, 14; AMTH 106; BIOE 120 or AMTH 108
Engineering core: ENGR 1, 1L; BIOE 1, 23, 24, 25, 45; track-specific engineering courses
Senior Design Project Sequence: BIOE 194, 195, 196
Technical Elective (TE): minimum 8 units (≥4 units upper-division BIOE); recommended courses across BIOE, biology, chemistry, physics, and other engineering
Notes on TE requirements, recommended courses, and track-specific lists not fully encoded

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Minimum total units required for major

otherNotes: In the Pre-med track, BIOL 1C may be replaced with BIOE 22.
BIOE 100 can only be taken up to two times.
Maximum of 6 units combined for co-ops, internships, and supervised independent research; non-BIOE units will not be credited.
The course not selected as a required course may count as a technical elective.

minors.name: Bioengineering
minors.description: Primarily designed for students in other disciplines to gain foundational bioengineering knowledge or complete prerequisites for medical school.

thingsNotEncoded: Lab components associated with each course are required.
Requirements must be accompanied by associated labs.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Studies (AIMES) minor offers a unique opportunity to explore the languages, cultures, histories, and traditions of a dynamic region that has shaped our world. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum spanning anthropology, art history, classics, ethnic studies, history, philosophy, political science, and religious studies, the minor prepares students for thoughtful engagement with current issues and diverse career paths.

minors.name: Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Studies
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor exploring languages, cultures, histories, and traditions of the Middle East and Islamic world.

thingsNotEncoded: Culture Courses: Students must complete six culture courses (two lower-division and four upper-division) relating to AIMES from at least three different departments; no more than two courses may be counted for AIMES credit from the department in which a student majors; a maximum of three courses may be taken from any one department.
Arabic Language: Three quarters of Arabic are required; students with prior relevant language knowledge may take a placement test to fulfill this requirement.
Senior Project: In lieu of one of the six required culture courses, students may elect an independent study/reading project in consultation with a member of the AIMES Faculty Advisory Council.

otherNotes: Students enrolled in the AIMES minor are strongly encouraged to participate in SCU-approved study abroad programs pertaining to Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern studies.
Director: Mohammed Kadalah, Ph.D.

deptsAndPrograms.name: General Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The School of Engineering, under the leadership of the chair of general engineering, offers a major in general engineering, a minor in general engineering, and a minor in technical innovation, design thinking, and the entrepreneurial mindset. This department is particularly well-suited for students at the intersection of multiple engineering disciplines or between engineering and other fields such as law, medicine, business, or education. It also offers a combined BS/MS program in engineering.

majors.name: Engineering
majors.description: The BS in Engineering is a modern, project-based, design-centered engineering curriculum that spans many engineering disciplines to train adaptable engineers with practical skills. It is designed for students to gain a broad understanding of the social, economic, ethical, and technical contexts in which technology is designed and used. The first two years focus on building breadth through diverse engineering disciplines, and the final two years allow students to develop technical depth via a tailored upper-division concentration and a senior design project.

thingsNotEncoded: Mathematics: Other approved upper-division mathematics elective
Engineering: Other approved programming course and lab including CSEN 11 and 11L, CSCI 10, or OMIS 30
Design Sequence alternatives: BIOE 194-196; CENG 192A-192C, 193, 194; CSEN 194-196; ECEN 194-196; MECH 194-196

otherNotes: Students must define an upper-division concentration in consultation with a faculty advisor

minors.name: Engineering
minors.description: The minor in engineering is a broad engineering curriculum that offers an introductory understanding of computer, electrical, civil, mechanical, and bio-engineering disciplines, serving both engineering majors seeking breadth and non-engineering majors seeking technical design knowledge to partner with engineers.

thingsNotEncoded: Programming: Other approved programming course together with any co-requisite labs

Additional two-course sequence selected from: BIOE 153 and 154; CENG 115 and 118; CENG 121 and CENG 143; CSEN 79 and any upper-division CSEN course; ECEN 100 and ECEN 110; ECEN 115 and (ECEN 116, 127, or 164); MECH 122 and MECH 132; MECH 123 and MECH 125; together with associated labs

minors.name: Technical Innovation, Design Thinking, and the Entrepreneurial Mindset
minors.description: This minor provides students with learning experiences in product innovation and prototyping, business fundamentals, design thinking and entrepreneurial fundamentals, and requires an experiential activity and elective component. An optional BioInnovation and Design track focuses on medical and healthcare applications.

thingsNotEncoded: Product Innovation and Prototyping (5 units): Option A: MECH 144/L; Option B: ENGR 2 and ENGR 110
Business and Commercialization Fundamentals (4 units): Option A: BUSN 70; Option B: ENGR 173 plus additional 1–2 unit courses from ENGR 164, 167, 168, 174, 175, 176, 178, BIOE 107
Design Thinking and Entrepreneurship Fundamentals (4 units): Option A: MGMT 164; Option B: BIOE 111; Option C: Four units from ENGR 162, 165, 166A, 166B, 169, 171A, 171B, 172A, 172B, 177, 179
Experiential Activity (5 units): Option A: ENGR 163 with senior project course sequence; Option B: ENGR 163 with ENGR 199 Directed Research; Option C: MGMT 198E Entrepreneurship Internship

Elective Component: Complete any two of the following program opportunities: Design Thinking Pathway with essay; approved co-/extra-curricular activities; independent study; additional 3 units from approved courses ENGR 16, 19, 110, 140, 145, 161; MGMT 6/6H; PHIL 26

emphases.name: BioInnovation and Design Track
emphases.description: An optional track to focus innovation, design, and entrepreneurial thinking on medical and health care applications.
emphases.nameOfWhichItAppliesTo: Technical Innovation, Design Thinking, and the Entrepreneurial Mindset

deptsAndPrograms.name: English
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of English provides a rich liberal arts education centered on literature, cultural studies, and writing.
