The English major integrates critical, professional, and creative writing across British, American, and global literatures, technical and professional communication, new media, and film, using diverse theoretical approaches with an emphasis on visual rhetoric and cultural studies. The department also offers minors in Creative Writing and Professional Writing, preparing students for skilled analysis and expression in academic and professional contexts.

majors.name: English
majors.description: The English major develops critical reading and writing skills through foundation courses, concentrations in literary/cultural studies and writing, and advanced seminar work, engaging British, American, and global texts and theoretical approaches.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Two historically grounded literary or cultural studies courses; at least one from a period before 1800.
Requirement: Three-course concentration in literary/cultural studies (American, British, Global, or individually defined); at least two upper-division.
Requirement: Three-course concentration in writing (professional writing and new media, or creative writing, or individually defined); at least two upper-division.
Requirement: One upper-division course in theory, or gender/sexuality, or ethnic/global studies (this course may also be used to meet another requirement).
Requirement: One senior seminar.
Note: The English Department does not allow students to challenge courses.

minors.name: English
minors.description: The English minor builds on foundation courses in literature and culture, supplemented by elective study in English.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Five English electives, four of which must be upper-division courses.

minors.name: Creative Writing
minors.description: The Creative Writing minor offers coherent training in poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction, including introductory courses, literary magazine production, electives, and an advanced writing course.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Two sections of Literary Magazine Production (ENGL91).
Note: English majors may use no more than two courses from the major to fulfill these requirements.

minors.name: Professional Writing
minors.description: The Professional Writing minor focuses on theories, ethics, and practice of writing in industry and public contexts, combining required courses, internship experience, and electives.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: At least 4 units of internship courses (ENGL189 and/or ASCI198 and/or ENGL198A/B).
Requirement: At least five electives (English 19, 20, 25, 26, 100–116, 181), three of which must be upper-division courses.
Note: English majors may use no more than two courses from the major to fulfill these requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Economics
deptsAndPrograms.description: As one of the social sciences, economics studies how individual choices—consumption, production, saving, investing, management, employment, citizenship, and voting—combine to determine how societies allocate scarce resources to produce and distribute goods and services. The program emphasizes rigorous, systematic analysis of issues such as wealth and poverty, unemployment, inflation, international trade, economic growth, and market success and failure, preparing graduates for careers in business, government, law, finance, education, consulting, and for graduate study in economics, business, public policy, or law.

majors.name: Economics
majors.description: The Bachelor of Science in Commerce in Economics integrates core economic theory with quantitative methods, requiring foundational courses in economics and mathematics, intermediate and advanced economics courses, and upper-division electives to prepare students for careers in business, government, consulting, and graduate study.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: At least two of the three upper-division economics electives must be completed after ECON 113 and ECON 115.

otherNotes: Prerequisite note: Unless otherwise noted, a grade of C- or better in ECON 1, 2, and 3 is required for all upper-division economics courses.

minors.name: Economics
minors.description: The Economics minor through the College of Arts and Sciences provides foundational economic theory and quantitative skills, requiring introductory and intermediate economics courses, a mathematics sequence, and additional upper-division electives.

emphases.name: Data Analysis for Economics
emphases.description: Provides economics majors with a structured program in econometrics and data analysis, applying quantitative methods to issues in economics and related fields.

thingsNotEncoded: All upper-division courses in the concentration can count as upper-division electives toward the economics major.

One (and only one) of the courses in list C may be substituted with: (a) an approved course in another social science or business discipline with a significant data analysis component; or (b) an independent study course with a substantial data analysis component (4 or 5 units). Substitutions must be approved by the Concentration advisor. Currently pre-approved substitutions: CSCI 183, ENVS 117, OMIS 114, OMIS 150. Non-economics courses will not count as one of the upper-division electives toward the economics major.

emphases.name: Mathematical Economics
emphases.description: Provides economics majors with a strong mathematical foundation through advanced mathematics and theoretical economics courses.

thingsNotEncoded: Recommendation: MATH 122 and MATH 123 are strongly recommended but not required.
Note: Students completing the mathematical economics concentration take MATH 11 and MATH 12 instead of MATH 30 and MATH 31.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Physics and Engineering Physics
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Physics and Engineering Physics offers Bachelor of Science degrees in Physics and Engineering Physics and a Physics minor. It provides lecture and laboratory instruction, research opportunities funded by DOE, NSF, NASA and private industry, and prepares students for graduate study or careers in diverse fields. Students often engage in faculty research through PHYS 198, internships, and fellowships. A student with a GPA below 2.5 must obtain department chair approval to declare a Physics or Engineering Physics major.

majors.name: Physics
majors.description: The Physics major leads to a B.S. in Physics, preparing students for graduate study or careers in industry, research, education, and other fields. It requires coursework in chemistry, mathematics, introductory and advanced physics, a computer science/engineering elective, and upper-division physics electives with a supplemental laboratory.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: CHEM 12 and CHEM 14 cannot both be taken for credit.

otherNotes: A student whose GPA is below 2.5 must obtain approval from the department chair to declare a Physics or Engineering Physics major.

majors.name: Engineering Physics
majors.description: The Engineering Physics major leads to a B.S. integrating fundamental physics and modern scientific developments with engineering and related technical coursework. It requires chemistry, mathematics, core physics with substitution options, a computer science/engineering elective, upper-division physics electives, technical electives, and a student-chosen technical cluster.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: CHEM 12 and CHEM 14 cannot both be taken for credit.
Note: MECH 121 substitution for PHYS 120 requires permission from an EP program advisor.
Requirement: Similar relevant courses might be considered as substitutions for technical electives subject to EP program advisor authorization.
Requirement: An approved cluster of five additional technical courses focused in a specific area chosen by the student and subject to advisor consent.

otherNotes: A student whose GPA is below 2.5 must obtain approval from the department chair to declare a Physics or Engineering Physics major.

minors.name: Physics
minors.description: Students pursuing a Physics minor must complete core introductory physics courses and additional upper-division physics coursework.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Theatre and Dance
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Theatre and Dance celebrates the creativity of the human spirit and offers a Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts with required emphasis in either Theatre or Dance.  It also offers minors in Theatre, Dance, Theatre Design and Technology, and Musical Theatre (in collaboration with the Department of Music).  The curriculum emphasizes academic rigor, artistic discipline, creative expression, mentorship by faculty, and hands-on performance and production experience.  Students work closely with advisors to plan their programs, participate in faculty-directed plays, dance concerts, festivals, and recitals, and develop skills in collaboration, critical thinking, and communication.  Graduates pursue careers in theatre or dance performance and teaching, arts administration, film, television, law, medicine, business, and more.

majors.name: Theatre Arts
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts requiring students to choose either a Theatre or Dance emphasis.  Theatre emphasis covers acting, design, theatre history/performance studies, dramatic literature, technical production, directing, and playwriting.  Dance emphasis covers modern/contemporary dance, choreography, dance history, ballet, jazz, hip-hop, and global dance forms.  Both conclude with a senior capstone project demonstrating proficiency.

minors.name: Theatre
minors.description: Minor in Theatre requiring foundational courses, an intermediate course, production participation, and upper-division electives.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Four upper-division Theatre and Dance electives

minors.name: Dance
minors.description: Minor in Dance requiring an introductory theatre course, ballet and jazz training, dance technique classes, a dance history course, one elective, and production participation.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: One course each in ballet and jazz (one at Level III)

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: One 5-unit upper-division Theatre and Dance elective

minors.name: Theatre Design and Technology
minors.description: Minor in Theatre Design and Technology requiring foundational theatre courses, a design/technology course, production participation, and three design-technology topic courses.

thingsNotEncoded: Production requirement: 4 units of THTR39/139 or THTR38 and 2 units of THTR39/139 with a makeup production element.

otherNotes: A separate minor in Theatre Design and Technology is not available to Theatre Arts majors.

emphases.name: Theatre
emphases.description: Theatre emphasis provides coordinated courses in acting, design, theatre history/performance studies, dramatic literature, technical production, directing, and playwriting.  Students complete a senior project demonstrating proficiency.

thingsNotEncoded: Senior Project description: capstone course requires public presentation, reflection on process, assessment of learning goals, and culminating oral presentation.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Three approved 5-unit upper-division theatre or dance electives

emphases.name: Dance
emphases.description: Dance emphasis provides coordinated classes in modern/contemporary dance, choreography, dance history, and training in ballet, jazz, hip-hop, and global dance forms.  Students complete a senior project demonstrating proficiency.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: One course each in ballet and jazz (one at Level III).

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sociology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Sociology equips students to engage in positive social change through diverse research methods and approaches, preparing them for a range of professional opportunities and graduate study while awakening the sociological imagination. Students may also choose to concentrate in one or more concentrations in the major.

majors.name: Sociology
majors.description: The sociology major requires foundational courses, a methods course, and a selection of electives to develop sociological skills and knowledge.

minors.name: Sociology
minors.description: The sociology minor consists of foundational courses and electives in sociology.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Gender and Sexuality Studies brings together scholars and scholarship on women and gender, areas that have come to occupy an increasingly important place in a number of disciplines in the last quarter century. Areas of inquiry include the participation of women in social and cultural production; the construction of gender and its role as a constitutive element of social, political, economic, and legal structures; feminist theory; and the development of ideas about femininities, masculinities, and sexualities. Gender is examined as it intersects with class, sexuality, ethnicity, disability, age, nationality, and the like. The Department of Gender and Sexuality Studies provides an integrated, interdisciplinary approach to understanding the social and cultural constructions of gender that shape the experiences of everyone. The curriculum offers a solid foundation in gender and sexuality studies, facilitating graduate study and careers involving gender justice concerns, and preparing students for leadership roles in diverse workplaces and communities.

majors.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
majors.description: The Gender and Sexuality Studies major requires 13 courses beyond the University Core Curriculum, including a Principles course or sequence, four required upper-division courses, a three-course concentration in one of three areas (Cultural Politics of Representation; Power, Rights, and Society; or Sexualities, Body Politics, and Social Structures), and five electives.

thingsNotEncoded: Concentration: A three-course concentration in one of three areas: Cultural Politics of Representation; Power, Rights, and Society; or Sexualities, Body Politics, and Social Structures.
Electives: Five electives.

minors.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
minors.description: The Gender and Sexuality Studies minor requires six courses, at least three of which must be upper-division, including a Principles course or sequence, one of GNSX 101 or 102, one of GNSX 190 or 105, and three electives.

thingsNotEncoded: Electives: Three electives.

emphases.name: Cultural Politics of Representation
emphases.description: Three-course concentration within the Gender and Sexuality Studies major focusing on cultural politics of representation.

emphases.name: Power, Rights, and Society
emphases.description: Three-course concentration within the Gender and Sexuality Studies major focusing on power, rights, and society.

emphases.name: Sexualities, Body Politics, and Social Structures
emphases.description: Three-course concentration within the Gender and Sexuality Studies major focusing on sexualities, body politics, and social structures.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Management and Entrepreneurship
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Management and Entrepreneurship curriculum emphasizes rigorous analysis and managerial application. Courses are offered in organizational behavior, human resource management, team dynamics, leadership, sustainability, and negotiations. Additional courses in strategic management, business ethics, entrepreneurship, new venture creation, and international management provide an overall leadership perspective.

majors.name: Management
majors.description: As a management major, you will be able to analyze complex business problems within the environment in which an organization operates and apply appropriate strategies to solve these problems. You will also develop sound ethical reasoning, interpersonal competencies, and leadership skills, and learn and use effective communication, teamwork, and group dynamics skills, preparing you for roles in for-profit and for-purpose organizations.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Students must fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum and Leavey School of Business requirements for the Bachelor of Science in Commerce degree.

otherNotes: Majors often enrich their academic experience by selecting a minor in entrepreneurship or international business, as well as directed studies, practicums, and internships.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Political Science
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Political Science department offers a Bachelor of Science in Political Science, introducing students to the analysis of political behavior, values, institutions, and governments, and preparing them for graduate and professional studies and careers in public service, research, nonprofits, and the private sector. The department supports field experiences and internships—including Washington, D.C., and congressional programs—and encourages study abroad. It also offers Power & Identity courses examining diversity, equity, and inclusion through a political science lens.

majors.name: Political Science
majors.description: The B.S. in Political Science requires foundational mathematics, introductory political science courses, and seven upper-division political science courses covering diverse subfields, electives, and a senior seminar.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Seven upper-division courses must include one lecture course from four of the five subfields (United States politics, comparative politics, international relations, political philosophy, and applied quantitative methods); two upper-division electives from any political science subfields (one may be a 5-unit internship class); and a political science senior seminar taken after achieving senior status or with instructor permission.

otherNotes: Students in the Political Science Honors Program must complete the requirements noted under the Honors Program.
It is recommended that majors complete POLI 99 before undertaking upper-division coursework in political science.

minors.name: Political Science
minors.description: For a minor in Political Science, students must complete three lower-division courses, three upper-division 5-unit political science lecture courses, and one additional political science course.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: Upper-division courses must be 5-unit lecture courses.
Note: ECON 1 or 2 cannot be substituted for POLI 40 for the minor.

emphases.name: Public Sector Studies
emphases.description: The public sector emphasis allows Political Science majors to focus coursework on public policy creation, implementation, and analysis, and on the operation of governments and public organizations. It provides a foundation for careers or graduate studies in public policy, administration, affairs, urban planning, and law. Contact the emphasis advisor for current details.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Grade of C or better in POLI 167.
Note: Equivalent internships, including Washington Semester Program internships, may count toward the POLI internship requirement.
Note: Other courses as approved by the emphasis advisor may count toward the additional lower-division and upper-division course requirements.

emphases.name: International Relations
emphases.description: The international relations emphasis focuses on the international system and interactions of national and non-national actors on the global stage. Topics include international organizations, transnational movements, conflict resolution, peace and reconciliation, military-strategic issues, international political economy, human rights, development and economic justice, and global sustainability. Contact the emphasis advisor for current details.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: POLI 116A and POLI 116B combined may count as a single course toward the three upper-division IR courses requirement.
Note: Other courses as approved by the emphasis advisor may count toward the international relations course requirement.
Requirement: One off-campus academic experience with an international relations component (study abroad, Washington Semester Program, Arrupe placement, or approved local internship) is required.

emphases.name: Pre-Law
emphases.description: The pre-law emphasis develops analytical and communication skills for law through courses inside and outside the Political Science department. At most six courses are required: three within the department and three outside; many fulfill other Core and major requirements. Contact the emphasis advisor for current details.

thingsNotEncoded: Note: Only one internship course may count toward the emphasis, and the internship must be law-related and approved by the emphasis advisor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Ethnic Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: Ethnic Studies is a dynamic, interdisciplinary discipline devoted to the critical examination of race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, class, and intersecting modes of inequality, focusing on the experiences of historically marginalized populations. The department fosters intersectional inquiry, serving as a resource for students across the university and connecting academic learning with community engagement and social change.

majors.name: Ethnic Studies
majors.description: The Ethnic Studies major provides advanced and concentrated training in racial and ethnic studies, with upper-division coursework clustered around six thematic areas: Community Engagement and Social Movements; Race, Law, Politics, and Policy; Intersectionality and Hybridity; Inequality and Education; Immigration, Transnationalism, and Globalization; and Social and Cultural Analysis. The program prepares students for careers in business, community service, education, law, medicine, social work, politics, and for graduate study.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: Six upper-division courses selected from at least four of the six thematic categories as listed.
Requirement: An upper-division elective in ethnic studies or from an approved list within any other department or program.

otherNotes: Note: No class can be used to fulfill more than one thematic category; any exception requires approval by the department chair.

minors.name: Ethnic Studies
minors.description: Minor in Ethnic Studies introduces foundational concepts and methods in critical racial and ethnic studies.
otherNotes: For course descriptions, see the listings of the relevant departments. Students should consult with the Ethnic Studies Department Chair to determine the applicability of courses taken at other institutions or in study abroad programs.

minors.name: Black Studies
minors.description: Minor in Black Studies (African American Studies) explores the histories, cultures, and experiences of African American communities.
otherNotes: For course descriptions, see the listings of the relevant departments. Students should consult with the Ethnic Studies Department Chair to determine the applicability of courses taken at other institutions or in study abroad programs.

minors.name: Asian American Studies
minors.description: Minor in Asian American Studies examines the histories, cultures, and experiences of Asian American communities.
otherNotes: For course descriptions, see the listings of the relevant departments. Students should consult with the Ethnic Studies Department Chair to determine the applicability of courses taken at other institutions or in study abroad programs.

minors.name: Latina/o/x Studies
minors.description: Minor in Latina/o/x Studies explores the histories, cultures, and experiences of Latina/o/x communities.
otherNotes: For course descriptions, see the listings of the relevant departments. Students should consult with the Ethnic Studies Department Chair to determine the applicability of courses taken at other institutions or in study abroad programs.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Communication
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Communication offers a program leading to a Bachelor of Arts in Communication, preparing students for careers in communication, entertainment, technology, journalism, and non‐profit industries, as well as for graduate study. The major integrates theory and practice in mass, interpersonal, strategic, global, and computer‐mediated communication. Students complete foundation, intermediate, and upper‐division courses; may apply approved study‐abroad courses as upper‐division electives; and are encouraged to undertake internships. The department also offers minors in digital filmmaking and journalism. All courses for the major or minor must be 4–5 units taken for a letter grade; practicum courses numbered 190–195 do not count toward the major or minor.

majors.name: Communication
majors.description: The Bachelor of Arts in Communication major requires foundation courses, intermediate courses, and upper‐division courses, preparing students for diverse communication careers and graduate studies.

thingsNotEncoded: Six elective upper‐division communication courses (COMM102-189 and COMM198)

minors.name: Journalism
minors.description: The Journalism minor requires one lower‐division course and six upper‐division journalism courses, with options to include practicum and courses from other departments with permission.

thingsNotEncoded: No more than one upper‐division elective may be taken from: COMM144, COMM145, COMM156, COMM166, COMM167, COMM169
A minimum of 5 units from repeated practicum courses (COMM190, COMM192) counts as one upper‐division course
Two upper‐division courses from another department may be accepted with permission of the journalism minor director

minors.name: Digital Filmmaking
minors.description: The Digital Filmmaking minor requires one lower‐division production course and six upper‐division courses from production and history/theory lists, with no more than two courses from the history/theory list.

thingsNotEncoded: No more than two courses may be taken from the history/theory courses (List II)
Six upper‐division courses must be selected from the production (List I) and history/theory (List II) lists

emphases.name: Global Media, Culture and Technology
emphases.description: This emphasis covers theoretical perspectives on global media, culture, and technology; history and political economy of global media industries; representation in various media; and audience reception and critical engagement to prepare students as global citizens.

emphases.name: Leadership Communication
emphases.description: This emphasis develops competencies in effective messaging, conflict management, intercultural communication, ethics, and leadership as a force for social change.

thingsNotEncoded: Special topics course approved by the emphasis director

emphases.name: Communication, Diversity and Culture
emphases.description: This emphasis examines communication’s role in constructing, reflecting, and managing diverse identities across interpersonal, organizational, institutional, and media contexts.

emphases.name: Digital Filmmaking
emphases.description: This emphasis trains students in writing, analyzing, and producing narrative and documentary film, encouraging experimentation with form, genre, and style.

emphases.name: Journalism
emphases.description: This emphasis instills ethical news judgment, research, interviewing, writing, and digital storytelling skills for journalistic practice and social justice.

thingsNotEncoded: No more than one upper‐division elective may be taken from: COMM144, COMM145, COMM156, COMM166, COMM167, COMM169
A minimum of 5 units from repeated practicum courses (COMM190, COMM192) counts as one upper‐division course

emphases.name: Strategic Communication
emphases.description: This emphasis focuses on planning and executing campaigns, using theory, data, and research to craft audiences, messages, media, and evaluation strategies for social impact.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Religious Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Religious Studies offers a Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies and a minor in theological and religious studies. In line with the Catholic and Jesuit tradition, it provides courses in Scripture, history, and Catholic theology, as well as a broad engagement with other religious traditions and methods. Department courses fulfill core-curriculum requirements at both lower- and upper-division levels and are organized into three areas: Theology, Ethics, and Spirituality (TESP); Scripture and Tradition (SCTR); and Religion and Society (RSOC).

majors.name: Religious Studies
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies

thingsNotEncoded: Three lower-division courses, one from each of the three areas (scripture and tradition; theology, ethics, and spirituality; and religion and society)
Eight approved upper-division courses
Four of the eight upper division courses consist of seminars from each of the three areas (RSOC, SCTR, TESP) and RELS 190 Seminar in Interreligious Dialogue

One of the eight upper division courses must be from the approved list of classes in Christian Theology: SCTR 111, SCTR 111R, SCTR 128, TESP 119, TESP 119R, TESP 124, TESP 124R, TESP 131/GNSX 149, TESP 131R/GNSX 149R, TESP 141, TESP 152, TESP 185, TESP 185R, TESP 196, TESP 196R

minors.name: Religious Studies
minors.description: Minor in Religious Studies requiring courses across introductory, intermediate, and advanced levels in the department’s three areas.

thingsNotEncoded: One introductory-level religious studies course (1–19)
Two intermediate-level courses (20–99)
Four approved advanced-level courses (100–199), one of which must be a religious studies seminar. Of the seven courses, at least one must be from each of the three areas (RSOC, SCTR, TESP).

deptsAndPrograms.name: History
deptsAndPrograms.description: The major program in history provides students with an understanding of the human experience through the analysis of evidence derived from both the recent and more distant past. As history majors, students learn essential skills, understand the breadth and similarities of the human experience, and acquire specific geographical and thematic knowledge. A degree in history provides excellent preparation for careers in education, journalism, media, government, law, business, and international affairs—all of which are careers that utilize the history major’s expertise in discovering, organizing, and analyzing the forces that shape the contemporary world.

majors.name: History
majors.description: The major program in history provides students with an understanding of the human experience through the analysis of evidence derived from both the recent and more distant past. As history majors, students learn essential skills, understand the breadth and similarities of the human experience, and acquire specific geographical and thematic knowledge. A degree in history provides excellent preparation for careers in education, journalism, media, government, law, business, and international affairs—all of which are careers that utilize the history major’s expertise in discovering, organizing, and analyzing the forces that shape the contemporary world.

thingsNotEncoded: Total courses: Students must complete a total of 13 history courses in addition to university Core Curriculum requirements.

Distribution: 4 lower-division courses (may include HIST 11A and 12A) and 9 upper-division courses, including six other upper-division courses and one seminar course taken after completing HIST 101S and 115 quarter units.

Field requirement: From among the student’s lower- and upper-division courses (excluding HIST 100 and 101S), at least one course from four of the following six fields: Global History, the United States and Canada, Latin America, Europe, East/South Asia, Africa/West Asia.
Optional senior project (HIST 197) may be taken as one of the required upper-division courses; required for Honors in History.
Seminar requirement: One seminar course must be taken after the student has completed both HIST 101S and 115 quarter units.

minors.name: History
minors.description: The minor in history requires seven history department courses, at least four of which must be upper-division.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Modern Languages and Literatures
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Modern Languages and Literatures educates students to be global citizens prepared to confront complex challenges in an interdependent world. Faculty integrate language and culture teaching to enable effective cross-cultural communication, cultural appreciation, critical interpretation of texts in sociocultural contexts, and analysis of problems across national boundaries. Rooted in Jesuit and liberal arts values, the department offers rigorous in- and out-of-classroom experiences that enrich students’ personal growth and prepare them for diverse careers.

majors.name: French and Francophone Studies
majors.description: Emphasizes French language proficiency and Francophone literary studies through required courses and electives.

thingsNotEncoded: At least one course in French and Francophone literatures.
Department-approved substitutions allowed for FREN 100 and 101.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives in French and Francophone studies to total 40 quarter upper-division units chosen with approval of the student's major advisor.

majors.name: Italian Studies
majors.description: Develops proficiency in Italian language, literature, and culture through required language courses and electives.

thingsNotEncoded: Department-approved substitutions allowed for ITAL 100 and 101.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives in Italian language, literature, and culture to total 40 quarter upper-division units chosen with approval of the Italian advisor.

majors.name: Spanish Studies
majors.description: Focuses on Spanish language, literature, and culture through specified course categories and electives totalling 40 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: Letter suffix courses (e.g., SPAN101M, SPAN101S) are also acceptable for the first requirement.
Advisor-approved equivalents allowed for SPAN 175, 176, or 177.
Courses used to satisfy one requirement cannot be reused for others.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Total of 40 upper-division units in Spanish Studies, of which at least 20 units must be taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

minors.name: Chinese and Sinophone Studies
minors.description: Provides a foundation in Chinese language and Sinophone studies through two tracks based on placement, leading to at least 19 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: Department-approved substitutions allowed for intermediate and advanced courses.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives to total at least 19 quarter units of upper-division work in Chinese and Sinophone Studies, with at least 10 units taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

minors.name: French and Francophone Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational French language and Francophone literary studies through required courses and electives totalling at least 19 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: At least one course in French and Francophone literatures.
Department-approved substitutions allowed for FREN 100 and 101.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives to total at least 19 quarter units of upper-division work in French and Francophone Studies, with at least 10 units taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

minors.name: Italian Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational Italian language and cultural studies through required courses and electives totalling at least 19 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: Department-approved substitutions allowed for ITAL 100 and 101.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives to total at least 19 quarter units of upper-division work in Italian, with at least 10 units taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

minors.name: Japanese Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational Japanese language and cultural studies through required courses and electives totalling at least 19 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: Department-approved substitutions allowed for JAPN 100, 101, and 102.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives to total at least 19 quarter units of upper-division work in Japanese, with at least 10 units taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

minors.name: Spanish Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational Spanish language and cultural studies through required courses and electives totalling at least 19 upper-division units.

thingsNotEncoded: Letter suffix courses (e.g., SPAN101M, SPAN101S) are also acceptable for the first requirement.
One upper-division elective must not duplicate earlier courses.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Remaining electives to total at least 19 quarter units of upper-division work in Spanish Studies, with at least 10 units taken at SCU or taught by SCU faculty.

specialPrograms.name: Military Science Program
specialPrograms.description: The Military Science Program offers classes open to Santa Clara University students and cross-enrolled students from Stanford University, San Jose State University, and UC Santa Cruz. It is designed to develop management skills and leadership abilities for successful careers in both the corporate world and the military. Students who complete the ROTC program are eligible for appointment and commissioning as officers in the United States Army.

thingsNotEncoded: Requirement: At least one undergraduate course from each of five designated fields of study.
Requirement: Prior to commissioning, cadets must take at least one course in military history.
Note: Exceptions to progression to the ROTC Advanced Course require approval by the Director of the Military Science Program.

otherNotes: Leadership laboratories, held weekly for three hours, are required of all students; performance during lab periods is reflected in the student’s course grade. Labs include activities such as terrain navigation, first aid training, virtual battle simulations, drill and ceremonies, and tactical leader development exercises.

Laboratory and field exercises require weekly lab work each quarter; two off-campus exercises are optional for non-scholarship ROTC Basic Course students and mandatory for ROTC Advanced Course students and contracted students.

specialPrograms.name: Study Abroad and Global Programs
specialPrograms.description: Global Engagement at Santa Clara University offers students opportunities to study abroad for a summer, quarter, or semester in a host‐country academic environment designed to enrich their college experience and foster responsible participation in a global society. Approved programs emphasize cultural integration, rigorous study, independent research, community‐based learning, and professional internships that can inform capstone projects. Programs during fall, winter, and spring are competitive and nomination‐based; summer programs are open.
otherNotes: Programs during fall, winter, and spring terms are highly competitive and require nomination; not all qualified applicants may be nominated.
Summer study abroad is non‐competitive; eligible after first, sophomore, or junior year.
Fall, winter, or spring study abroad may be undertaken only once during an undergraduate career.
Students are encouraged to plan early with their academic advisor and to attend Study Abroad 101 sessions.

Refer to the Global Engagement website for complete policies on eligibility; standards of conduct; withdrawals; program costs & financial aid; grading, transcripts, and pass/no pass; approved and non‐approved programs; accessibility accommodations; participation process; and ethics.
The department reserves the right to alter or eliminate programs at any time or to redirect students due to institutional considerations.
Priority admission may be given to applicants for Santa Clara University’s own programs, including exchanges.

specialPrograms.name: Summer Sessions
specialPrograms.description: The Summer Sessions Office coordinates a comprehensive schedule of undergraduate courses in most academic departments from June through September. Over 140 courses are offered on campus and online in three-, five-, and ten-week accelerated sessions, with content, prerequisites, and units equivalent to regular terms.
otherNotes: Academic Regulations: Summer sessions follow most regular academic regulations, except the Administrative Cancellation of Course Enrollment policy is not in effect.

Administrative Cancellation: Students remain enrolled and financially responsible unless they formally drop; non-attendance does not relieve tuition obligation; un-dropped courses result in an “F” grade and holds on the student account.
Auditing Courses: See Chapter 8 of the Undergraduate Bulletin for auditing information.

Course Load Limits: No exceptions; students may enroll in no more than 10 units during Sessions 2 and 3; during Sessions 4, 5, and 6, students may enroll in only one intensive lab science course at a time and may not concurrently enroll in Session 1, 2, or 3 courses if taking an intensive lab science.
Course Cancellations: SCU reserves the right to change schedules or policies without prior notice; cancellation notifications are sent to students’ @scu.edu email addresses.

Enrollment and Course Restrictions: Students must formally enroll and pay tuition by published deadlines; instructor signature alone does not constitute enrollment; late registrations/adds are not accepted beyond the add period; ineligible enrollment may result in administrative withdrawal.
Independent Study: Eligible students may pursue independent study with faculty approval; see Chapter 8 of the Undergraduate Bulletin.
Internships: Contact individual departments and programs for information about summer internships.
New Fall Transfer Students: Transfer students accepted for fall quarter should contact the Senior Record and Transcript Analyst before registering for summer classes.
Incoming First-Year Students: Not eligible to enroll in Summer Sessions unless participating in an eligible University summer program; contact the Summer Sessions Office.

specialPrograms.name: Aerospace Studies (AFROTC Detachment 045)
specialPrograms.description: AFROTC Detachment 045 at San José State University is a four-year, 16-unit leadership development program open to Santa Clara University students. In tandem with their degree, cadets cultivate physical fitness and leadership skills, participate in field training, leadership laboratories, and professional officer courses, and prepare for commissioning into the U.S. Air Force or U.S. Space Force.

thingsNotEncoded: Field Training: 3-week summer training between sophomore and junior years at Maxwell AFB required for continuation.
Leadership Laboratory: Weekly cadet-led sessions for hands-on leadership, drill, ceremonies, and mentoring.
Physical Training: Twice-weekly fitness sessions designed to meet commissioning physical standards.
General Military Course: First two years of DAF history, customs, and leadership principles.
Professional Officer Course: Final two years focusing on leadership roles, mentoring, and commissioning preparation.

otherNotes: Crosstown Enrollment: SCU students register through the SCU catalog and commute weekly to SJSU for AS classes, LLAB, and PT.
Scholarships: In-College Scholarship Program (Type 1 full tuition; Type 2 up to $18K/year) and General Charles McGee Leadership Award; all require minimum 2.5 GPA and do not cover room/board.
Commitment: Contracted cadets commit to at least four years of active duty upon commissioning.
Graduate Programs: Options include the Graduate Law Program, USUHS, AFHPSP, tuition assistance (up to $250/semester hour, $4,500/year), and AFIT master’s programs.

specialPrograms.name: LEAD Scholars Program
specialPrograms.description: The LEAD Scholars Program is a program for first-generation college students (i.e., students whose parents did not graduate from a four-year college or university) focused on academic success, student leadership, and community engagement. The LEAD Scholars Program provides academic and vocational development opportunities, holistic advising, peer mentoring, and community building through a variety of courses, programs, and support networks.

thingsNotEncoded: Prerequisite: ENGL1A is a prerequisite for ENGL2A.
Requirement: ENGL 1A and 2A sequence reserved for LEAD scholars only.

specialPrograms.name: University Honors Program
specialPrograms.description: The University Honors Program offers small, seminar-style classes across the humanities, natural and social sciences, business, and engineering. It emphasizes critical thinking, analytical rigor, effective communication, and close interaction between faculty and students. Honors coursework often fulfills Core requirements and culminates in a focused, collaborative senior thesis. The program is open to majors from any undergraduate field and welcomes students from diverse backgrounds.

thingsNotEncoded: Level I requirements: Critical Thinking and Writing I; Critical Thinking and Writing II; Cultures and Ideas I; Cultures and Ideas II; HNRS 20 (Difficult Dialogues seminar); either a Core RTC I, 2, or 3 Honors or a Core Ethics Honors course; three UHP electives or experiences; Senior Honors Thesis (one full academic year).

Level II requirements: HNRS 20 (Difficult Dialogues seminar); either a Core RTC I, 2, or 3 Honors or a Core Ethics Honors course; four UHP electives or experiences; Senior Honors Thesis (one full academic year).

UHP Electives may include: designated Honors courses or other approved upper-division humanities courses; study abroad or summer study abroad (counts as one elective if over six weeks, ½ if under six weeks); extra language course (counts as one elective); immersion trip through SCU Ignatian Center (counts as ½ elective, repeatable once); UGST 101 (counts as ½ elective); select LEAD Scholars courses.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Total Honors-level courses for students entering at Level I
Total Honors-level courses for students entering at Level II

otherNotes: A cumulative 3.3 GPA is required to graduate with Honors.
Membership is contingent on adherence to the SCU Student Conduct Code; violations may result in removal from the program.
Honors Contract courses allow students to earn Honors credit for non-Honors courses via an enrichment project; application must be submitted by the end of the first week of the quarter.

courses.name: Business Leadership Skills
courses.description: Designed to continue learning from MGMT 71 by focusing on leadership skills specific to a business environment. Course integrates group discussion, selected readings, experiential learning, and reflective engagement experiences.

courses.name: Business Law
courses.description: This course provides the student with an overview of the legal system and primary substantive areas of law affecting business transactions including the law of contracts, torts, property, employment, business associations, securities, and white collar crime. Students exercise critical thinking and writing skills through the application of fundamental legal principles in the business context.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of 45 quarter-units prior to enrollment
Permission of instructor required for enrollment

courses.name: Contemplative Leadership and Sustainability Program (CLASP)
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with opportunities to learn and rehearse contemplative leadership practices and explore the relationship between personal values, business, and sustainability. CLASP introduces students to issues of sustainability in industry, provides face-to-face encounters with professionals and companies/organizations already “doing the work” of sustainability, and immerses students in the region’s natural and social environments via daylong weekend excursions. Assignments include keeping a weekly journal, weekly readings, small and large group discussions, writing a short paper, and completing a group project.

courses.name: Feeding the World
courses.description: In this course, students examine the global system for the production and distribution of food, assess the ability of the system to satisfy the human demand for food, and evaluate the impact of the system on the natural environment. Students will employ tools from statistics, operations, and economics to describe, analyze, and forecast imbalances between food supply and food demand. Through a term project, students use their new skills to examine the food system in a developing nation experiencing chronic hunger.

courses.name: Food, Hunger, Poverty, Environment Immersion
courses.description: This course is designed to help students meet their social justice-oriented experiential learning requirements (ELSJ) while learning about issues related to food production and consumption, hunger, poverty, and the environment. The course blends short lectures, guided discussions and reflections, and a 11- to 14 day immersion in a selected country interacting with local people of diverse backgrounds for experiential active learning. The goal is to increase students’ understanding of the role of business in the developing world and to explore the role of business in alleviating poverty through economic development and the pursuit of social justice. Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.

courses.name: Food, Hunger, Poverty, Environment Immersion
courses.description: This course is designed to help students meet their social justice-oriented experiential learning requirements (ELSJ) while learning about issues related to food production and consumption, hunger, poverty, and the environment. The course blends short lectures, guided discussions and reflections, and a 11- to 14 day immersion in a selected country interacting with local people of diverse backgrounds for experiential active learning. The goal is to increase students’ understanding of the role of business in the developing world and to explore the role of business in alleviating poverty through economic development and the pursuit of social justice. Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.

courses.name: Contemporary Business for Nonmajors
courses.description: This course is specifically designed for upper-division (junior and senior), non-business majors who are interested in learning about business firms and their relation to both the global and local environment in which they operate. Course will use a business simulation as a key learning method, in addition to lectures and small group discussion. This course is not open to students who have completed BUSN 70.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of at least 87.5 quarter-units prior to enrollment

courses.name: Effective Communication in Business
courses.description: In this pragmatic professional development course, students will learn the following business communication skills: business writing, informal and formal presentations, networking, and personal brand. Students will produce quantitative and qualitative analyses and evaluations and create professional multimedia projects, proposals, and presentations. Students will also develop skills in formal and informal business writing and discourse (briefings, reports, emails, memos, interviews, social media, infographics, etc.).

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of Critical Thinking & Writing 1 and 2 prior to enrollment
Completion of at least 88 quarter-units prior to enrollment

courses.name: Global Experience Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for business students to study global business issues in specific countries or regions around the world. The practicum includes selected readings, several special lectures on topics related to the target country or region, and an in-country learning session, typically two weeks after the end of spring quarter. Each practicum is led by a Leavey School of Business faculty member who travels with the students to the country to lead integration sessions, guide discussions, and generally enhance the student’s learning experience.

courses.name: LSB Community Fellows Seminar
courses.description: This seminar is completed in tandem with a community organization internship through the LSB Community Fellows program. Participants study the context of economic opportunity in the nonprofit/government sector, reflect on internship experiences, and develop professional skills. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Community Fellow
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Community Fellow.

courses.name: Field Studies: NPI Small Business Improvement Project
courses.description: In this two-quarter course, students work directly with a small business in a local, economically disadvantaged neighborhood. Students conduct an analysis of the business owner’s goals, develop an action plan, and implement the plan to improve business performance. The purpose of the Neighborhood Prosperity Initiative is to provide a unique learning opportunity for undergraduate students and to contribute to the economic growth and prosperity of a local neighborhood in a sustainable, ethical, and effective way. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires participation in community-based learning (CBL) experiences off campus.
Students must complete two consecutive quarters in winter and spring.

courses.otherOfferingSchedule: Winter and Spring quarters (must be taken consecutively)

courses.name: LSB Peer Advising Practicum
courses.description: A practicum experience for Leavey School of Business Peer Advisors, which provides the opportunity to learn, apply, and integrate training and experience to provide prescriptive advising for undergraduate business students. Course includes 5 quarterly class meetings plus 1-4 hours per week of direct advising experience. Graded P/NP only.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Peer Advisor
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Peer Advisor.

courses.name: The Global Fellow Experience
courses.description: This course is designed for students involved in the Global Fellows program. The introductory course introduces students to the macro issues and challenges faced by the underserved populations of the world and provides a context for evaluating the global costs of injustice. Through the framework of business and organizational operations, students develop the tools to evaluate best practices as applied to living a civic life. Students will be exposed to academic research, guest speakers, interactive exercises, and readings in preparation for their summer fellowship, where the course learning will be applied to a work experience.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Global Fellows program participant.

courses.name: The Global Fellow Experience
courses.description: The reflection course segment is designed for students who spent time during the summer as Global Fellows. The primary goal of the course is to allow each student to reflect upon their experience and deepen their lessons learned. The secondary goal is to have the Global Fellows share their experience with the SCU community, thus bringing awareness of global issues to a wider audience.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Global Fellows program participant.

courses.otherNotes: In certain cases, the reflection segment course will fulfill the ELSJ University Core requirement.

courses.name: Leadership Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for business students to obtain advanced experience in leading, facilitating, directing, evaluating, and advising within a Leavey School of Business schoolwide or interdisciplinary project, class, or initiative. This practicum generally includes selected readings, reflective engagement activity, personal leadership assessment, and writing assignments.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires approval of the assistant dean.

courses.description: Opportunity for upper-division students—typically involved with schoolwide or interdisciplinary programs, projects, or initiatives—to work and study in or with for-profit and nonprofit organizations. This practicum generally includes selected readings, a reflective engagement activity, and a written report.

courses.name: Child Studies
courses.description: Designed to cultivate critical awareness, thinking, and action with respect to children and families in schools and broader communities. The course fosters an understanding of social justice issues related to children and youth in schools and communities, historical movements and organizational structures within education, and the emerging professions of child studies.

courses.name: Cultural Humility with Children and Families
courses.description: Cultural humility involves the lifelong, ongoing critical development of awareness, attitudes, knowledge, and skills that create supportive and transformative interactions when working with children and families within diverse environments. This course is designed to cultivate knowledge of self and others while also promoting a formative anti-oppression framework. Through readings, films, discussion, and trainings, we will devote ourselves to the rigorous examination of personal, interpersonal, and systemic/structural racism, classism, (hetero) sexism, ageism, adultism, ableism, and religious discrimination toward the pursuit of social justice with children and families.

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: CHST 4-1 - Cultural Competence and Humility with Children and Families

courses.name: Compassionate Leadership and Mindfulness
courses.description: Explores current research on how mindfulness (cultivating self-awareness and relational-awareness) leads to essential workplace leadership competencies such as: leading courageous conversations, managing conflict and emotions, and developing resilience in challenging situations. Students analyze how mindfulness programs impact the role businesses and public organizations (e.g., schools, prisons) play in civic life.

courses.name: Anti-Racist & Decolonial Praxis in Early Childhood Contexts
courses.description: Children witness and make meaning of racialization and racialized inequity in society. Grounded in transdisciplinary theories and research, this course (1) examines racialized inequity in the context of early childhood, and (2) applies an array of community-led, anti-racist, and decolonial praxis frameworks toward early childhood equity, accessibility, inclusion, belonging, and thriving in domains such as early care and education, health, housing, and the environment.

courses.name: Quantitative Research Methods and Statistics in Child Studies
courses.description: An introduction to research methods and exploratory data analysis, descriptive statistics, probability, sampling, estimation, and statistical inference. Work problems are focused on how statistics are used in evaluating and understanding questions about children in school and community settings.
courses.otherNotes: PSYC51 fulfills the CHST11 requirement for psychology double majors.

courses.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Child Studies
courses.description: An introduction to qualitative research methods and analysis of discourse, context, and the social construction of truth. Focus is on research questions related to evaluating and understanding familial, social, and political issues related to children. Emphasis is on the production of knowledge, interpretive frameworks, and research design.

courses.name: Movement Education
courses.description: An exploration of movement as a primary site of learning and meaning-making for children and youth. Students learn how to facilitate learning in the conceptual/cognitive, affective/socio-emotional, and psychomotor/kinesthetic domains, and reflect critically on the teaching process. Course culminates in student-led collaboratively designed lessons taught to children from neighboring K–8 schools.

courses.name: Technology and Education
courses.description: Explores the relationship between technology, society, and education. Students investigate the appropriate role of technology in educational reform, evaluate the personal impact of social media on children and adolescents, and propose solutions to the pressing educational needs of our society. Interactive and engaging discussions and team projects highlight the dynamic quality of these issues.

courses.name: Advanced Writing for Research in Social Sciences
courses.description: Explores quantitative and qualitative social science research on children, youth, and families, with a focus on the relationship between a research problem, the exploration of that problem, and the inferences that can be drawn from empirical inquiry. Students engage in close readings of scholarly articles while planning and participating in lessons to support collective learning. Emphasis on the development of skills in social science writing for academic audiences.
courses.prerequisiteCourses: (CTW1 & CTW2 & CHST11 & CHST12) | (CTW1 & CTW2 & PSYC51 & CHST12)

courses.name: Early Childhood, Family and Community
courses.description: An overview of theory and research of infancy and early childhood (ages 0–5). Specific topics vary and the course may be repeated for credit.

courses.description: An interdisciplinary examination of children in middle childhood (ages 5–12). Specific course topics vary and the course may be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Advocacy for Children
courses.description: An interdisciplinary examination of child and family advocacy and the prevention of child abuse and neglect within a risk and resilience framework.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires participation in community-based learning experiences off campus

courses.name: Urban Education and Multiculturalism
courses.description: This course explores the social and political forces shaping inequality in urban schools and beyond. Special attention is paid to the role of US institutions, political ideologies, and historical events, examining the way unequal structures produce unequal outcomes. The course also delves into philosophical reflections on education policy, neoliberalism, standardized testing, tech in education, the social construction of merit, and much more. Last, students dare to “imagine otherwise,” while exploring possibilities for structural change and a world where inequality and injustice no longer exist.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires participation in community-based learning experiences off campus

courses.name: Children, Art, and Society
courses.description: This course allows students to investigate the role of art and creativity in human development and understand the personal and societal impact of accessible, high quality, embodied arts experiences. The way the arts creates a path for more justice in the world, democratizes the classroom for English language learners, gracefully assists with classroom management, and fosters higher order thinking is explored, as is the notion of public schools offering all arts to all students. Student learning in this course culminates with transdisciplinary perspectives, acknowledging the powerful complexity and potential of the arts to serve as a bridge between diverse fields and perspectives creating new epistemologies. Final research papers have students investigating arts education efforts and organizations dedicated to the most pressing issues of our time (democracy, peace, diplomacy, the environment, migration, economic and social disparities, etc.), and offering imaginative analysis of ways to better serve the human family, particularly children and youth, via generative, creative, artful solutions.

courses.name: Special Topics: International Internship/Study
courses.description: Topics may vary.

courses.name: Media and Youth
courses.description: See COMM154Y.

courses.name: Exceptional Child
courses.description: Introduction to childhood mental, intellectual, and developmental processes. We examine how education, medical, and governmental institutions represent and address what is commonly referred to as “behavior disorders,” “communication (speech and language) disorders,” “hearing impairments,” “physical and health impairments,” “severe disabilities,” and the “gifted and talented.” We place special emphasis on the social, political, and historical processes shaping notions of competency, dis/ability, and giftedness.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires participation in community-based learning experiences off campus

courses.name: Internship in Child Studies
courses.description: The Internship in Child Studies course provides students with an opportunity to work in schools and community settings that support children, youth and families. Students apply their knowledge to authentic circumstances while exploring what it means to live and work in solidarity with children, youth and families. In addition, students strengthen their ability to “walk in accompaniment” thoughtfully, sensitively, and respectfully with communities experiencing economic, social, and/or political marginalization or oppression.

courses.name: Senior Capstone I
courses.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to develop a research project and learn through direct engagement with children in school, family, or community settings. Students will be guided as they review the literature, devise a research question, and design and pilot research procedures.

courses.description: Students will complete their research project developed in CHST 181 including data collection and analysis, writing a research paper in APA style, and presenting a research poster.

courses.name: Resilient Families
courses.description: A community-engaged guided research experience focused on promoting well-being and resilience in children and families.
courses.otherNotes: P/NP only; May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Future Teachers Project Seminar
courses.description: A seminar addressing education and the teaching profession for students participating in the Future Teachers Project (FTP). This program has a three-fold purpose: (1) offer students opportunities to take part in scholarly research and the production of knowledge, with special attention to urban contexts, (2) organize in-class discussions regarding the nexus of educational inequality, politics, and resistance movements, and (3) hold workshop sessions to increase the competitiveness of FTP scholars for graduate school, as they apply for fellowships, scholarships, and internships.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Only for students admitted into the Future Teachers Project

courses.name: Directed Reading/Directed Research
courses.description: Independent study or supervised research project with a faculty sponsor from CHST.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Proposal for enrollment is due before finals week of the previous quarter

courses.name: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
courses.description: Using an evolutionary framework, we examine how past and current human variation is measured, our place in nature, human genetics, human and nonhuman primate biology and behavior, the primate and hominin fossil record, and the origin and meaning of human biological and behavioral variation. Students gain experience in biological anthropology methods, data analysis and interpretation, and the theoretical frameworks that guide our understanding of what it means to be human. Laboratory 15 hours.

courses.name: Introduction to Archaeology
courses.description: How do archaeologists understand the past? This course examines the methods, theories, and analytical techniques that archaeologists use to study the past and interpret ancient cultures. Selective survey of human cultures over time in different regions of the world. Laboratory 15 hours.

courses.name: Introduction Cultural Anthropology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the subject matter, research methods, and applications of cultural anthropology. Its purpose is to help students understand how different human groups think and live, how they cope with life’s demands and expectations, and how they make sense of the world. In order to gain additional experience with diverse cultural groups, students are required to participate in off-campus Arrupe partnerships.

courses.name: Vanished Peoples and Lost Civilizations
courses.description: “Popular archaeology” is addressed by examining past societies, human migrations and cultural contacts, and ancient human behavior and technologies. Ideas and assumptions found in movies and other popular media will be evaluated in light of current archaeological data and theory.

courses.name: Popular Culture and Bioanthropology
courses.description: From King Kong to Clan of the Cave Bear, students examine popular culture interpretations of biological anthropology. After reviewing the history of biological anthropology, we analyze popular avenues (film, cartoons, newspapers, fiction) through which the public has been informed about human variation, the human fossil record, primate behavior, and human genetics.

courses.name: Screen Time: Culture, Film, and Media in the 21st Century
courses.description: This course uses anthropological perspectives and methods to explore how popular media shapes, creates, and transforms our understanding of culture, identity, and social relationships in the 21st century. This course is not just about culture, difference, and identity, but also about how we learn about and intersect with cultural and identity formation processes through various forms of media. Throughout the course we will use feature-length films as starting points for thinking critically about culture, gender, class, race/racism, economics, ideology, family, kinship, and violence. We will also be critically discussing how film and media shape our perceptions and understandings of the complex, global, and highly socially mediated world in which we live. One of the core premises of this course, following Bird and Godwin (2006), is that we cannot simply assume that media “speaks for itself.” Building upon the work of cultural and media anthropologists, and the late Neil Postman, the primary goal of this course is to push students to take a more active, and anthropologically informed, approach to the highly mediated world in which we live.

courses.name: Field Course in Archaeological Methods
courses.description: On-site archaeological field research with practical experience in the basic techniques of excavation and data analysis. Students will gain experience in mapping, stratigraphic excavation, and field processing of finds. Laboratory component will include community outreach, cataloging, and relevant special analyses.

courses.name: Cultures & Ideas I
courses.description: A two-course sequence focusing on a major theme in human experience and culture over a significant period of time. Courses emphasize either broad global interconnections or the construction of Western culture in its global context. Courses may address measuring humanity, peace and violence, social change in the Middle East, migration and transnationalism, and other topics.

courses.description: This course explores world geography through examination of contemporary global problems including poverty and inequality, political conflict, environmental crises, and natural disasters. Pathways :: Sustainability

courses.name: Anthropological Theory
courses.description: This course provides a historical survey of the development of different areas of anthropological theory. By exploring original and secondary writings, students are able to understand how theoretical frameworks differ from each other and how anthropology has evolved as a discipline. Required for majors and minors in anthropology. Students should take this class no later than the winter quarter of their junior year.

courses.name: Archaeological Methods
courses.description: Introduction to the techniques of discovery and analysis that archaeologists have found useful in research. Special attention to sampling techniques in survey and excavation. Laboratory analysis will consider techniques for measuring parameters of past demography, diet, craft specialization, and exchange.

courses.name: Ethnographic Methods
courses.description: This course provides a survey of ethnographic methods and techniques used in anthropological research. Students will develop critical thinking and practical skills related to research project design and implementation, ethical dilemmas and solutions in research contexts, and data analysis in support of ethnographic writing and practice.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Grade of C- or better in ANTH1, ANTH2, and ANTH3
Special permission of the department chair

courses.name: Senior Capstone
courses.description: An in-depth writing intensive senior seminar in anthropology. Topic will change annually. Required for majors in anthropology.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Grade of C- or better in ANTH112
Special permission of the department chair

courses.name: Primate Behavioral Ecology
courses.description: This course focuses on the theoretical frameworks that guide primate behavioral studies, including in-depth empirical exploration of adaptation, comparative primate behavior, ecology, field studies, and classification. Critical evaluation of core concepts in primate behavioral ecology as well as data collection, presentation, and interpretation in primate field studies are reviewed.

courses.name: Paleoanthropology
courses.description: How do we know what we think we know about human evolution? Students explore this question by reading primary literature, examining fossil and comparative data, and exploring current technology for interpreting hominin evolution. Class reviews evolutionary theory and the varying applications of paleoanthropological analysis to understanding past and present variation.

courses.name: Human Nutrition and Culture
courses.description: Study of the biocultural interactions that shape dietary patterns and nutritional status of modern humans. Focus on the evolution of the human diet and nutritional requirements; the basic principles of human nutrition and nutritional assessment; and the social, technological, and political factors that influence the nutritional health of human societies today.
