We will also discuss how the research in cognitive neuroscience relates to various aspects of our daily life, including topics on AI, neuro-ethics, decision-making, morality, culture, and law.

courses.name: Truth and Consequences: Challenging What and How We Know
courses.description: How do you know something to be true? We explore that fundamental question by examining different ways of knowing, pursuing a more nuanced and sophisticated understanding. We question how we come to construct and accept existing beliefs in psychology, communication, and the general public by challenging what we believe we know to be true. Drawing on humanities, arts, and sciences we will pursue developing critical thinking with the goal of enhanced decision-making reflecting cura personalis.

courses.name: Adolescent Development
courses.description: A focus on development during the second decade of life, from puberty through early adulthood. Topics include physical, intellectual, and social development; identity; sexuality; changing social contexts; and life transitions.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Pathways :: Children, Family and Society

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Applied Data Science for Psychologists
courses.description: In this class, we will explore a few advanced methods to study human behaviors and cognition. Statistical techniques such as Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) and generalized linear models (GLM) will be introduced to analyze complicated cross-sectional and longitudinal datasets, and some state-of-art machine learning methods such as classification, clustering, and neural network models will be explained and introduced. Students will learn some theoretical backgrounds as well as practice examples of these methods with a heavy emphasis on hands-on practices. In addition, some basic data science skills such as data management and coding in R/RStudio will be practiced.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Developmental Psychology
courses.description: Seminar examines contemporary topics in developmental psychology. Original research, current trends, and special focus on ongoing research and applied programs will be highlighted. Focus of seminar can be children and adolescent development or young adult development.

courses.name: Identity
courses.description: Identity is a prominent construct in several sub-disciplines within psychology, including developmental, social, personality, gender, and cross-cultural. In addition, issues of identity increasingly are recognized as an important factor affecting our behavior and beliefs. Identity politics, ethnic and racial biases, and the #TimesUp movement are but three examples of the central role of identity in current events. The purpose of this class is to understand the multifaceted nature of identity and how it has been examined in psychology.

courses.name: Psychology of Gender
courses.description: This course examines research on the psychology of gender. Students will learn the leading theories of gender, as well as how gender can be scientifically studied. This course will discuss real world issues surrounding gender (e.g., stereotypes, sexism, the gender pay gap, objectification, etc.) and their potential solutions.

courses.name: Infancy
courses.description: This course will investigate the psychological development of humans from conception through toddlerhood to age three. It will include relevant genetic theory, physical, perceptual, and motor development, neurological and cognitive development, early temperament and social development, and individual differences. We will explore how these areas of growth interact within individuals as they build on their earliest foundations during the most rapidly unfolding period of life. We will unpack the unique research methods used to understand and assess these areas of development. And, students will learn first-hand about the practical applications of understanding how typical developmental progresses.

courses.name: Developmental Psychology
courses.description: An upper-division survey of child development, including infancy, early childhood, middle childhood, and a brief introduction to adolescent issues. Major developmental theories and methods of studying development are introduced. Principal findings regarding social-emotional, cognitive, and physical development in the different stages of childhood are included, as well as findings about the impact on development of the societal context in which development occurs.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Pathways :: Children, Family and Society

courses.name: Psychology of Religion and Spirituality
courses.description: The discipline and principles of psychology and human behavior in understanding religion and spirituality. Topics include empirical research and theory on religious and spiritual behavior and transformation from the various religious, spiritual, and historical wisdom traditions. Contemplative practices and spiritual tools from the various religious/spiritual wisdom traditions for psychological and physical health will be highlighted. A spiritual formation project will help students experience a hands-on activity to examine their own spiritual formation and development. This course is inclusive in that no particular religious/spiritual tradition or any tradition affiliation is assumed or required, and also highlights evidence-based empirical approaches.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: PSYC1 or PSYC2 and a RTC1 class

courses.name: Peer Leadership
courses.description: Students enrolled in this course will participate in training designed to help them serve in a peer leadership role within the psychology department. Attendance at regular meetings and workshops is required and will be facilitated by a Psychology Faculty Advisor. After training, students will be assigned the role of Peer Advisor and will meet with fellow psychology majors to help them with course planning, course selection, and to assist with questions about the major.
courses.otherNotes: Restricted to psychology majors; may be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Psychology of Aging
courses.description: Development in later life. Topics include theories of aging and development; cognition, perceptual, and social changes in aging; mental health issues in the elderly; and abnormal aging, such as Alzheimer’s disease.

courses.name: Psychology Labs
courses.description: Psychology labs vary by topic. Lab assistants will work on projects up to 10 hours per week, as determined by the faculty research supervisor. Students accepted to a lab will register via permission number with their supervisor.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Registration via permission number with faculty research supervisor

courses.name: Internship/Practicum
courses.description: A course where students can learn how they can best apply classroom instruction to their career objectives through academically supported work experience. Internships at Santa Clara University are closely monitored for appropriateness and practical application. Internships should encourage career skills and professional growth. Internships serve to introduce the student to the range of opportunities afforded a degree in the discipline. Students are expected to represent the University in a professional manner and to act responsibly with the client and the assignments. Selected readings. Open to upper-division students with a GPA of 3.0 or higher who have received permission from a faculty sponsor.
courses.otherNotes: Note: If taken for 5 units, students should select 198E when enrolling. PSYC198E may be used for an upper division psychology elective.

courses.name: Directed Reading/Directed Research
courses.description: Independent projects undertaken by upper-division students with a faculty sponsor. To receive course credit, the student must submit a formal written proposal and have it approved by the sponsoring faculty member and the department chair. The proposal must be submitted before the end of the previous quarter and must meet University requirements for independent study credit.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Formal written proposal approved by sponsoring faculty member and department chair before the end of the previous quarter

courses.otherNotes: If taken for 5 units, students should enroll in 199E to receive credit for an upper division psychology elective, OR enroll in 199A if they would prefer that the units count toward the Advanced Topics requirement for the major instead.

courses.name: Hands-On Physics!
courses.description: How do scientists know what they “know?” The course is taught in a “Workshop Physics” style emphasizing hands-on experimentation and timely topics in today’s world. Instrumentation and “learning by doing” are emphasized. Includes student-designed, peer-reviewed group projects.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

courses.name: Introduction to Astronomy: The Solar System
courses.description: An introduction to astronomy with a particular focus on the origin and evolution of the solar system, planets, and their satellites. Topics include a brief history of the science of astronomy, telescopes and observational methods, gravitation, spectra and the sun, asteroids, comets, astrobiology, searches for new planetary bodies, and Earth science. Students should be familiar with arithmetic and basic algebra.
courses.otherNotes: Evening observational lab meets five times during the quarter.

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: PHYS 2-1 - Introduction to Astronomy: Solar L and L (-)
nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: PHYS 2-2 - Introduction to Astronomy: Solar L and L (-)
nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

courses.name: Introduction to Astronomy: The Universe
courses.description: An introduction to astronomy with a particular focus on the origin and evolution of the universe, galaxies, and stars. Topics include a brief history of the science of astronomy, understanding the night sky and phases of the moon, telescopes and observational methods, gravitation, spectra and the sun, the big bang, and the expansion and ultimate fate of the universe. Special emphasis is given to stellar evolution, from the birth of stars to their ultimate demise, and stellar remnants such as neutron stars and black holes. Students should be familiar with arithmetic and basic algebra.
courses.otherNotes: Evening observational lab meets five times during the quarter.

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: PHYS 3-1 - Introduction to Astronomy: The Universe (-)
nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: PHYS 3-2 - Introduction to Astronomy: The Universe (-)
nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

courses.name: The Physics of Dance
courses.description: An exploration of the connection between the art of dance and the science of motion with both lecture/discussion sessions and movement laboratories. Topics include mass, force, equilibrium, acceleration, energy, momentum, torque, rotation, and angular momentum. Movement laboratory combines personal experience of movement with scientific measurements and analysis, in other words: “dance it” and “measure it.” This is a lab science course, not a dance technique course.

courses.name: Physics and Technology for Future Leaders
courses.description: Examples of how science and technology impact daily life are ubiquitous. Each day brings new comforts and challenges to communities around the world. Leaders in government, industry, finance, and elsewhere are expected to make important and impactful decisions every day on issues related to power consumption, new materials technology, transportation, terrorism, global resources, radiation, climate change, energy sources, conservation, and more. To make the best decisions, leaders must be literate in modern science and technology. This course aims to help students understand the need-to-know physics behind many of the debates impacting our world today. Most importantly, the course aims to give students, the future leaders of our world, the basic tools needed to independently and critically analyze technologically relevant material presented in the media everyday. Assumes basic algebra only.

courses.name: Physics of Music
courses.description: The course explores the physical foundations underlying the production, propagation, and perception of music. No prior knowledge of either physics or music is expected, and math will be restricted to basic algebra and trigonometry. At the end of this course, students should possess a basic understanding of the nature of sound; the basic workings of string, wind, and brass instruments, as well as the human voice and ear; knowledge of basic musical notation; and a familiarity with some acoustical problems and their solutions. Through laboratory investigations, students will become familiar with methods of scientific exploration and gain an appreciation of the experimental method.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

courses.name: Introduction to Space Sciences
courses.description: An introduction to space exploration and how observations from space have influenced our knowledge of Earth and of the other planets in our solar system. This is synthesized within the context of the field of astrobiology, an interdisciplinary study of the origin of the universe, and the evolution and future of life on Earth.

courses.name: General Physics I
courses.description: One-dimensional motion. Vectors. Two-dimensional motion. Newtonian laws of motion. Law of gravitation. Planetary motion. Work. Kinetic and potential energy. Linear momentum and impulse. Torque and rotational motion. Rotational energy and momentum. Equilibrium. Elastic deformation of solids. Density and pressure of fluids. Bernoulli’s principle. Buoyant forces. Surface tension. Includes weekly laboratory.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the instructor is required

courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

courses.name: General Physics II
courses.description: Temperature. Thermal expansion of solids and liquids. Thermal energy. Heat transfer. Specific heat. Mechanical equivalent of heat. Work and heat. Laws of thermodynamics. Kinetic theory of gases. Ideal gas law. Entropy. Vibration and wave motion. Hooke’s Law. Sound. Electric charges, fields, and potential. Gauss’s Law. Ohm’s Law. Potential difference. Electric potential. Capacitors. Electric current. Resistance and resistivity. Electric energy and power. Kirchhoff’s Rules. RC circuits. Magnetic fields and forces. Ampere’s Law. Induced EMF. Faraday’s Law. Lenz’s Law. Self-inductance. Includes weekly laboratory.
courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

courses.name: General Physics III
courses.description: RLC series circuit. Power in an AC circuit. Resonance. Transformers. Optics: reflection, refraction, mirrors, and lenses. Total internal reflection. Diffraction. Young’s double slit interference. Polarization. Optical Instruments. Relativity. Wave-particle duality. Photoelectric effect. X-rays. Pair production and annihilation. Bohr Atom. Spectra. Uncertainty principle. Radioactivity. Nuclear particles and reactions. Subnuclear particles. Includes weekly laboratory.
courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

courses.name: Physics for Scientists and Engineers I
courses.description: Measurement. Vectors. Straight-line kinematics. Kinematics in two dimensions. Laws of inertia, mass conservation, and momentum conservation. Center-of-mass and reference frames. Force. Newtonian mechanics and its applications. Gravitation. Kepler’s Laws. Work and kinetic energy. Potential energy and energy conservation. Rotational dynamics. Statics. Includes weekly laboratory.
courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

courses.name: Physics 31H Honors Supplement
courses.description: Weekly seminar for 15–20 students that extends the treatment of PHYS 31 topics to more challenging/thought-provoking problems. The seminar is being offered so that PHYS 31 can count for Honors credit. Students who are not in the Honors Program but who have a strong math background and some physics experience, and who want the added fun of working on intriguing problems and solution techniques, may also enroll.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Restricted to Honors Program students or those with strong math background and some physics experience

courses.name: Physics for Scientists and Engineers II
courses.description: Fluids. Thermodynamics. Simple harmonic motion. Waves. Sound. Interference, diffraction, and polarization. Quantization of light and matter waves. Blackbody radiation and the photoelectric effect. Bragg diffraction and X-ray spectra. Wave-particle duality. Includes weekly laboratory.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the instructor is required

courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

courses.name: Physics 32H Honors Supplement
courses.description: Weekly seminar for 15–20 students that extends the treatment of PHYS 32 topics to more challenging/thought-provoking problems. The seminar is being offered so that PHYS 32 can count for Honors credit. Students who are not in the SCU Honors Program but have a strong interest in physics or math, and who want the added fun of working on intriguing problems and solutions techniques, may also enroll.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Restricted to Honors Program students or those with strong interest in physics or math

courses.name: Physics for Scientists and Engineers III
courses.description: Electrostatics. Gauss’s Law. Potential. Capacitance. Electric current. Resistance. Kirchhoff’s rules. DC circuits. AC circuits. Magnetic force. Ampere’s Law. Electromagnetic induction. Includes weekly laboratory.
courses.otherNotes: The PHYS 31/32/33 sequence and the PHYS 11/12/13 sequence cannot both be taken for credit.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Explorations :: Natural Science

courses.name: Physics for Scientists and Engineers IV
courses.description: Special relativity. Historical development of modern physics: black body radiation, photoelectric effect, Compton scattering, X-rays, Bohr atom, DeBroglie wavelength, Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Quantum waves and particles. Schrödinger equation. Nuclear structure and decay. Particle physics. Introduction to semiconductors. Includes weekly laboratory.

courses.name: Electronic Circuits for Scientists
courses.description: Linear electric circuits. DC analysis, network theorems, phasor AC analysis. Diode circuits. Physics of p-n junction. Junction diodes, field-effect devices, bipolar junction transistors. Elementary amplifiers. Small-signal device models. Logic gates, digital integrated circuits, Boolean algebra, registers, counters, memory. Operational amplifier circuits. Linear amplifier bias circuits. Includes weekly laboratory.

courses.name: Numerical Methods in Physics
courses.description: Basic elements of programming in MATLAB. Ordinary and partial differential equations. Fourier transforms and spectral analysis. Linear regression and curve fitting. Numerical integration. Stochastic methods. Selected applications include planetary motion, diffusion, Laplace and Poisson equations, and waves. Weekly computer lab. Prior exposure to basic linear algebra will be helpful but is not required.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: CSCI10 or COEN10 or MECH45 recommended

courses.name: Analytical Mechanics
courses.description: Calculus of variations. Hamilton’s principle. Lagrangian and Hamiltonian approaches to classical dynamics. Central force motion. Noninertial reference frames. Dynamics of rigid bodies. Selected topics in classical dynamics such as coupled oscillators, special relativity, and chaos theory.

courses.name: Electromagnetic Theory I
courses.description: Review of vector calculus. Dirac delta function. Electrostatic fields. Work and energy. Laplace and Poisson equations. Separation of variables. Fourier’s trick. Legendre equation. Multipole expansion. Computational problems.

courses.name: Electromagnetic Theory II
courses.description: Magnetostatics. Induced electromotive forces. Maxwell’s equations. Energy and momentum in electrodynamics. Electromagnetic stress tensor. Electromagnetic waves. Potential formulation. Computational problems. Dipole radiation.

courses.name: Advanced Electromagnetism and Optics
courses.description: Geometric optics. Polarization and optically active media. Interferometry. Optical signal and noise in detection and communication. Interaction of light with metals, dielectrics, and atoms. Thermal radiation. Laser operation. Most students will take 113 and 113L simultaneously.
courses.otherNotes: Also listed without lab as ELEN725.

courses.name: Advanced Electromagnetism and Optics Lab
courses.description: Weekly lab to accompany PHYS 113. Most students will take PHYS 113 and PHYS 113L simultaneously.

courses.name: Physics of Solids
courses.description: Crystal structure. Phonons. Free electron theory of metals. Band theory of solids. Semiconductors. Electrical and thermal transport properties of materials. Magnetism. Superconductivity. Topics from current research literature. PHYS 116 is taught as a capstone course.

courses.name: Thermal Physics
courses.description: Laws of thermodynamics with applications to ideal and non-ideal systems. Kinetic theory of gases. Entropy. Classical and quantum statistical mechanics. Bose and Fermi systems. Selected topics from magnetism, materials, and low-temperature physics.

courses.name: Quantum Mechanics I
courses.description: The Schrödinger equation. The wave-function and its interpretation. One dimensional potentials. Harmonic oscillator. Methods in linear algebra including matrix operations, unitary transformations and rotations, eigenvalue problems and diagonalization. Hilbert space, observables, operators, and Dirac notation. The hydrogen atom. Angular momentum.

courses.name: Quantum Mechanics II
courses.description: Angular momentum and spin. Electrons in EM field. Addition of angular momenta. Identical particles. Time-independent perturbation theory. Fine and hyperfine structure. Time-dependent perturbation theory and its application to light-matter interaction. Fermi’s golden rule.

courses.name: Quantum Mechanics III
courses.description: Variational principle. WKB approximation. Scattering theory. Single-particle relativistic quantum theories. Quantum paradoxes. Introduction to quantum electrodynamics and/or quantum computation: qubits, quantum gates and circuits, quantum teleportation, quantum algorithms, error correction codes. Quantum computer implementations.
courses.otherNotes: Most students will take PHYS 123 and PHYS 123L simultaneously.

courses.name: Quantum Mechanics III Lab
courses.description: Weekly lab to accompany PHYS 123. Most students will take PHYS 123 and PHYS 123L simultaneously.

courses.name: Modern Topics in Physics
courses.description: A course focused on a topic in current physics research selected by junior and senior Physics majors in consultation with department faculty. Recent topics have included quantum information and quantum computation, quantum paradoxes, superconductivity and magnetism, general relativity, and high-energy physics.

courses.name: Advanced Laboratory
courses.description: Students conduct intensive laboratory-based experiments in the areas of atomic, nuclear, quantum and condensed matter physics, RF detection, signal processing and more. Emphasis on in-depth understanding of underlying physics, experimental techniques, data analysis, and dissemination of results. Additional design and implementation of independent table-top project also required. Introduction to LabVIEW programming and LaTeX. Written and oral presentations.

courses.name: Introduction to Astrophysics
courses.description: A survey of astronomy for science majors focused on the physics and mathematics that astronomers use to interpret observations of planets, stars, and galaxies. Topics include the kinematics of objects in the solar system, the nature of stars and their evolution, and the evolution and formation of galaxies.

courses.name: Cosmology
courses.description: A survey of cosmology for science majors. Much of the course will focus on the properties of an idealized, perfectly smooth, model universe. Topics include the formation of galaxies and clusters in an evolving universe, the Benchmark Model of the universe, dark matter and dark energy, the cosmic microwave background and its fluctuation spectrum, recent results from such experiments as WMAP and Planck, Big Bang nucleosynthesis, and problems with the standard Big Bang models and inflation theory.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Knowledge of calculus through differential equations is assumed

courses.name: Biophysics
courses.description: Diffusion and dissipation in cells. Friction and inertia in biological systems. Entropic and chemical forces. Macromolecules. Molecular machines. Ion pumps. Nerve impulses.

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Advanced topics in selected areas of physics. Enrollment by permission of instructor.

courses.name: Physics and Society
courses.description: Colloquium course that focuses on Physics research topics with significant societal impact. Weekly speakers come from academia, the private sector, industry, non-profits, and government laboratories. Students participate in weekly discussions and write short reflection papers.

courses.name: Undergraduate Physics Research
courses.description: Departmental work under close professorial direction on research in progress. Permission of the professor directing the research must be secured before registering for this course.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the professor directing the research must be secured before registering

courses.name: Directed Reading in Physics
courses.description: Detailed investigation of some area or topic in physics not covered in the regular courses; supervised by a faculty member. Permission of the professor directing the study must be secured before registering for this course.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the professor directing the study must be secured before registering

courses.name: The Nature of Mathematics
courses.description: For students majoring in arts and humanities. Topics chosen from set theory, logic, counting techniques, number systems, graph theory, financial management, voting methods, and other suitable areas. Material will generally be presented in a setting that allows students to participate in the discovery and development of important mathematical ideas. Emphasis on problem solving and doing mathematics.

courses.name: Finite Mathematics for Social Science
courses.description: Introduction to finite mathematics with applications to the social sciences. Sets and set operations, Venn diagrams, trees, permutations, combinations, probability (including conditional probability and Bernoulli processes), discrete random variables, probability distributions, and expected value.

courses.name: Introduction to Statistics
courses.description: Elementary topics in statistics, including descriptive statistics, regression, probability, random variables and distributions, the central limit theorem, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing for one population and for two populations, goodness of fit, and contingency tables.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Foundations :: Mathematics

courses.name: Precalculus
courses.description: College algebra and trigonometry for students intending to take calculus. Does not fulfill the undergraduate Core Curriculum requirement in mathematics. Students with credit for calculus are not admitted to Math 9 without permission.

courses.name: Precalculus Lab
courses.description: Focus on active learning to prepare students for calculus. Does not necessarily coordinate topics with MATH 9 on a weekly basis. Instead, the lab sessions are designed to help students to build overall strength in non-routine problem solving.

courses.name: Calculus and Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Limits and differentiation. Methods and applications of differentiation. Ordinarily, only one of MATH 11, 30, or 35 may be taken for credit. Note: MATH 11 is not a suitable prerequisite for MATH 31 or 36 without additional preparation.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Passing grade on the Calculus Readiness Exam

courses.name: Series and Differential Equations
courses.description: Sequences, series, and analytic functions. Use of explicit, numerical, and series methods to solve ordinary differential equations. Complex numbers.

courses.name: Calculus for Business I
courses.description: Differentiation and its applications to business, including marginal cost and profit, maximization of revenue, profit, utility, and cost minimization. Natural logarithms and exponential functions and their applications, including compound interest and elasticity of demand. Study of the theory of the derivative normally included in MATH 11, except trigonometric functions not included here.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Passing grade on the Calculus Readiness Exam

courses.name: Calculus for Business II
courses.description: Integration and its applications to business, including consumer surplus and present value of future income. Functions of several variables and their derivatives. Emphasis throughout the sequence on mathematical modeling, the formulation of practical problems in mathematical terms.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A grade of C- or higher in MATH30 is strongly recommended before taking this course

courses.otherNotes: Only one of MATH12, MATH31, or MATH36 may be taken for credit. Note: MATH11 and MATH35 are not suitable prerequisites for this course without additional preparation.

courses.name: Calculus for Life Sciences I
courses.description: Modeling with functions, limits, and derivatives. Derivative rules and tools. Applications to the life sciences.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Passing grade on the Calculus Readiness Exam
A grade of C- or higher in MATH9 is strongly recommended before taking this course

courses.otherNotes: Ordinarily, only one of MATH11, MATH30, or MATH35 may be taken for credit. Note: MATH35 is not a suitable prerequisite for MATH12 or MATH31 without additional preparation.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Core Foundations :: Mathematics

courses.name: Calculus for Life Sciences II
courses.description: Integration, differential equations, and probability. Applications to the life sciences.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A grade of C- or higher in MATH35 is strongly recommended before taking this course

courses.otherNotes: Only one of MATH12, MATH31, or MATH36 may be taken for credit. Note: MATH11 and MATH31 are not suitable prerequisites for this course without additional preparation.

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Predicate logic, methods of proof, sets, functions, sequences, modular arithmetic, cardinality, induction, elementary combinatorial analysis, recursion, and relations.

courses.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra
courses.description: Groups, homomorphisms, isomorphisms, quotient groups, fields, integral domains; applications to number theory.

courses.name: Linear Algebra
courses.description: Vector spaces, linear transformations, algebra of matrices, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and inner products.

courses.name: Lower-Division Seminars
courses.description: Basic techniques of problem solving. Topics in algebra, geometry, and analysis.

courses.name: Writing in the Mathematical Sciences
courses.description: An introduction to writing and research in mathematics. Techniques in formulating research problems, standard proof methods, and proof writing. Practice in mathematical exposition for a variety of audiences.
courses.otherNotes: Course may not be taken to fulfill any mathematics or computer science upper-division requirements for students majoring or minoring in mathematics or computer science.

courses.name: A Survey of Geometry
courses.description: Topics from advanced Euclidean, projective, and non-Euclidean geometries. Symmetry.

courses.name: Advanced Calculus
courses.description: Topics to be chosen from the following: Open and closed subsets of R^n, the definition of limits and continuity for functions on R^n, the least upper bound property on R, the intermediate and extreme value theorems for functions on R, the derivative of a function on R^n in terms of a matrix, the matrix interpretation of the chain rule, Taylor's theorem in multiple variables with applications to critical points, the inverse and implicit function theorems, multiple integrals, line and surface integrals, Green’s theorem, Stokes’ theorem, the divergence theorem, and differential forms.

courses.name: Advanced Linear Algebra
courses.description: Abstract vector spaces, dimensionality, linear transformations, isomorphisms, matrix algebra, eigenspaces and diagonalization, Cayley-Hamilton Theorem, canonical forms, unitary and Hermitian operators, applications.

courses.name: Theory of Functions of a Complex Variable
courses.description: Analytic functions. Cauchy integral theorems, power series, conformal mapping. Riemann surfaces.

courses.name: Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Topics from the theory of groups.

courses.name: Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: Rings and ideals, algebraic extensions of fields, and the Galois theory.

courses.name: Topology
courses.description: Topological spaces and continuous functions. Separability and compactness. Introduction to covering spaces or combinatorial topology.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Pathways :: Paradigm Shifts and the Nature of Human Knowing

courses.name: Probability and Statistics I
courses.description: Sample spaces; conditional probability; independence; random variables; discrete and continuous probability distributions; expectation; moment-generating functions; weak law of large numbers; central limit theorem.

nextQuarterOfferings.courseTags: Pathways :: Paradigm Shifts and the Nature of Human Knowing
Pathways :: Paradigm Shifts and the Nature of Human Knowing
Pathways :: Paradigm Shifts and the Nature of Human Knowing

courses.name: Probability and Statistics II
courses.description: Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. Maximum likelihood estimation. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and analysis of categorical data. Simple and multiple linear regression. Optional topics may include sufficiency, the Rao-Blackwell theorem, logistic regression, and nonparametric statistics. Applications.

courses.name: Mathematical Finance
courses.description: Introduction to Ito calculus and stochastic differential equations. Discrete lattice models. Models for the movement of stock and bond prices using Brownian motion and Poisson processes. Pricing models for equity and bond options via Black-Scholes and its variants. Optimal portfolio allocation. Solution techniques will include Monte Carlo and finite difference methods.
courses.otherNotes: Also listed as FNCE116, FNCE3489, and AMTH367.

courses.name: Logic and Foundations
courses.description: Deductive theories. Theories and models. Consistency, completeness, decidability. Theory of models. Cardinality of models. Some related topics of metamathematics and foundations.

courses.name: Set Theory
courses.description: Naive set theory. Cardinal and ordinal arithmetic. Axiom of choice and continuum hypothesis. Axiomatic set theory.

courses.name: Mathematical Models
courses.description: Matching the real world with mathematical structure using such things as differential equations, difference equations, and stochastic processes, at the instructor’s discretion. Topics related to continuous or discrete models may be selected from topics, including the following: qualitative analysis, simulation, parameter estimation, steady-state analysis, shock waves, random walks, Markov chains, agent-based models, and cellular automata.

courses.name: Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Linear partial differential equations with applications in physics and engineering, including wave (hyperbolic), heat (parabolic), and Laplace (elliptic) equations. Solutions on bounded and unbounded domains using Fourier series and Fourier transforms. Introduction to nonlinear partial differential equations.

courses.name: Optimization I
courses.description: Methods for finding local maxima and minima of functions of multiple variables in either unconstrained or constrained domains: the Hessian matrix, Newton’s method, Lagrangians, Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions. Convex sets, convex functions, and convex programming. Methods for determining functions that optimize an objective like maximizing profit or minimizing task completion time: calculus of variations, optimal control, and both deterministic and stochastic dynamic programming.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Grade of C- or better in CSCI10 or prior programming experience is required

courses.name: Optimization II
courses.description: Algorithms for computing local and global optima. Numerical methods for finding local optima, including gradient descent and Nelder-Mead. The simplex method for linear programming and the duality of zero-sum games. Metaheuristics for approximating global optima.

courses.name: Intermediate Analysis I
courses.description: Rigorous investigation of the real number system. Concepts of limit, continuity, differentiability of functions of one real variable, uniform convergence, and theorems of differential and integral calculus.

courses.name: Intermediate Analysis II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH153.

courses.name: Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description: Systems of linear differential equations with constant coefficients. Numerical methods and applications. Autonomous systems, critical points, and stability of linear and nonlinear systems. Elementary Liapunov theory. Existence and uniqueness of solutions.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: CSCI10 and either MATH22, MATH23, or AMTH106 recommended

courses.name: Numerical Analysis
courses.description: Numerical algorithms and techniques for solving mathematical problems. Linear systems, integration, approximation of functions, solution of nonlinear equations. Analysis of errors involved in the various methods. Direct methods and iterative methods.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Grade of C- or better in CSCI10 or equivalent

courses.name: Development of Mathematics
courses.description: A selection of mathematical concepts with their historical context.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Upper-division standing in a science major

courses.name: Problem Solving
courses.description: Use of induction, analogy, and other techniques in solving mathematical problems.

courses.name: Differential Geometry
courses.description: Introduction to curves and surfaces. Frenet-Serret formulas, Gauss’ Theorema Egregium, Gauss-Bonnet theorem (as time permits).

courses.name: Theory of Numbers
courses.description: Fundamental theorems on divisibility, primes, congruences. Number theoretic functions. Diophantine equations. Quadratic residues.

courses.name: Combinatorics
courses.description: Permutations and combinations, generating functions, recursion relations, inclusion-exclusion, Pólya counting theorem, and a selection of topics from combinatorial geometry, graph enumeration, and algebraic combinatorics.

courses.name: Graph Theory
courses.description: Selected topics from planarity, connectedness, trees (enumeration), digraphs, graph algorithms, and networks.

courses.name: Cryptography
courses.description: History, classical cryptosystems, stream ciphers, AES, RSA, discrete log over finite fields and elliptic curves, and signatures. This course followed by CSCI181.
courses.otherNotes: This course is followed by CSCI181.

courses.name: Upper-Division Seminars
courses.description: Advanced topics in algebra, geometry, or analysis. Research projects.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Research project supervised by a faculty member in the department.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the professor directing the research must be secured before registering

courses.name: Math Education and Social Justice
courses.description: This course will examine issues of social justice surrounding mathematics education in U.S. public schools. Topics include problem solving and pedagogical methods, learning challenges, diversity, accessibility, and educational technology. Students will explore these topics while interacting with local students in high schools that serve students from traditionally marginalized communities. Students will provide support and guidance to precalculus students and serve as higher education role models, while also gaining insight into public mathematics education issues through personal interactions with teachers and students. Students will learn, reflect, analyze and integrate through their personal interactions, structured written reflections, in-class discussions, and a final project which helps address these issues.
courses.otherNotes: Satisfies the ELSJ requirement, but does not count towards a math major or minor.

courses.name: Advanced Topics
courses.description: Areas of mathematics not ordinarily covered in regularly scheduled courses, often areas of current interest.

courses.name: Internship/Practicum
courses.description: Guided study related to off-campus practical work experience in mathematics or statistics. Enrollment restricted to majors or minors of the department.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Restricted to majors or minors of the department

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Reading and investigation for superior students under the direction of a staff member. This can be used only to extend, not to duplicate, the content of other courses.

courses.name: Introduction to Computing and Applications
courses.description: An overview course providing multiple perspectives on computing. Students will learn the structures of computer programming without writing code, gain high-level understanding of important computing systems such as the Internet and databases, and discuss the impact of technology on society.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer Science
courses.description: Introduction to computer science, and computer programming in Python. Basic programming structures, conditionals, loops, functions, recursion, arrays. Topics relating to the applications of and social impact of computing, including privacy, artificial intelligence, computation in physics, psychology, and biology. Discussion of cryptography, computation through history, networks, hardware, and basic runtime analysis. Includes weekly lab.
courses.otherNotes: CSCI10 may be taken for credit if the student has received credit for CSEN10, but not CSEN11 or a similar introductory programming course, or CSCI60.

courses.name: Introduction to C++ and Object-Oriented Programming
courses.description: Basic object-oriented programming techniques using C++: abstract data types and objects; encapsulation. The five phases of software development (specification, design, implementation, analysis, and testing). Memory management and pointers. Includes weekly lab.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Grade of C− or better in CSCI10 or equivalent

nextQuarterOfferings.sectionName: CSCI 60-1 - Introduction to C++ and Object-Oriented Programming
